urn:contentItem:5RJ0-V921-JBVM-Y07P-00000-00FF to discuss ban in primary schools;Party's spokeswoman on children says protection of our children is urgent2018-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8,9FF to discuss ban in primary schoolsParty's spokeswoman on children says protection of our children is urgentSenan Molony; James Ward

ALL primary schools should consider banning smartphones, Fianna Fáil has suggested.

The main Opposition party has yet to settle on a firm policy - it will now engage in widespread consultations - but its spokeswoman for children and youth affairs said yesterday: 'A child doesn't need a smartphone in primary school.' Anne Rabbitte made her comments as senior Cabinet member Eoghan Murphy admitted that his views on regulating smartphone use by children have changed as a result of the ongoing debate.

This has followed on from a concerted campaign by the Irish Daily Mail to restrict the age limit on smartphone ownership.

Ms Rabbitte said: 'There is no need for any child to be bringing a smartphone into a national school.' She said Fianna Fáil would now consult on the question of a minimum age for possession of an internet-capable device.

Fianna Fáil is to establish a Spewould cial Working Group on Child Internet Safety. Party spokesman on mental health, TD James Browne, warned that the dangers of smartphone dependence were now well established.

'They include depression, anxiety, body dysmorphia - a long list. And there has been very little action by the State. Children are having silent conversations with strangers and we are not regulating what is taking place online.' He added: 'In 2012, ownership of a smartphone passed 50% of the population and since that time mental health problems associated with their use has increased exponentially.' The party wants the office of a Digital Safety Commissioner established as a matter of urgency, noting that the idea appeared to have been kicked into the long grass by the Taoiseach last autumn, only to be brought back to the fore by a string of horror court cases, culminating in the conviction of 26-year-old paedophile Matthew Horan last week. The predator preyed on children as young as nine from his bedroom, blackmailing them into sending him nude photographs and threatening to post them to their friends, even though the children said they kill themselves if he did so. Ms Rabbitte said it had been 16 months since the Law Reform Commission had urged action to better protect minors online. 'There should be a Digital Safety Commissioner now to protect our youth and to give some comfort to parents,' she said.

'We have to keep our kids safe from trolls and shocking instances of predators. At the moment our children are not being protected by the industry.' She added: 'The big platforms don't engage at the moment because they don't have to. There are no controls.' She instanced the case of the CEO of Snapchat declining to come before an Oireachtas committee late last year, even though Facebook had already done so.

Ms Rabbitte said: 'Social media companies are setting their own rules and regulations because there's a void there. The State needs to get involved.' She said the working group within the party would be asking what particular powers and 'teeth' people wanted a digital safety watchdog to have, but certainly there should be instant take-down where someone requested the removal of a compromising photograph or image.

Children as young as six are accessing apps, she said, adding that there is also an issue surrounding inappropriate advertising that can be on app pages. Mr Browne said bullying had been part of the human condition since 'year zero' but with cyberbullying there was now no escape and it followed children home.

Ms Rabbitte said both Government and the industry had a duty of care to young Irish citizens and she hoped that political proximity to Big Tech - which has been wooed by the IDA and which provides a lot of employment in Ireland - did not play a part in delaying the establishment of a new watchdog, or on the age of internet accounts being set at 13, rather than 16.

Meanwhile, Housing Minister Eoghan Murphy has said hearing from experts such as Dr Mary Aiken - who told the Mail last week that she wants children under the age of 14 to be prevented from using the devices - had changed his view on the Government introducing legislation on the matter. Asked by the Mail if he would support introducing age restrictions on smartphones, he replied: 'My views on this are kind of changing actually.

'The more I hear people who are experts in the field talk about this, the more I hear Dr Mary Aiken speak about this and the need for us to give some guidance to parents as to smartphone usage, the more I tend to agree with her to be honest. But we're still having this discussion as a government and there is a summit now scheduled for March which will be quite important.' The minister also revealed that the issue had been discussed by the Government at Cabinet level, but he said he was speaking in a personal capacity.

Ms Rabbitte has also spoken about the online abuse she is regularly subjected to by 'nasty individuals', sometimes on a daily basis. She told the Mail that she is the target of 'shocking' comments on social media, and was labelled a 'murderer' by online trolls during her time on the committee that discussed repealing the Eighth Amendment.

'I spend half an hour every night sitting down blocking people and trying to figure out who are really interested, who really care, who really want to engage, who are interested in what I say or do, or who is there just waiting for the next swipe,' she said.

'There is no level of humanity in some of these people. The anger, the aggression, is shocking.' Comment - Page 14 senan.molony@dailymail.ie

urn:contentItem:5RDN-C711-JCCP-S34B-00000-00Fiat rules out Jeep sale2018-01-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:39ZLexisNexisNEWSFiat rules out Jeep sale

Fiat Chrysler Automobiles CEO Sergio Marchionne confirms Jeep will not be sold to Chinese car maker GAC to raise cash

Fiat   Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) boss Sergio Marchionnehas put to bed speculation that   Jeepcould be sold off to raise money or that the whole group could be sold to a Chinese manufacturer such as   GAC.

"We have no intention of breaking up the company or giving it to the Chinese," Sergio Marchionne, whose company builds cars in China with GAC,confirmed at the Detroit motor show.

"We have a very good partner in GAC. They have global ambitions, they want to come to the US and we're talking to them about if and how they can accomplish that. None of that is designed to impact on the independence of FCA."

Marchionne, who will retire from his position in 2019, went on to confirm the importance of strong brands in a potential future of autonomous and electrified vehicles. He stressed that vehicles risked being reduced to 'commodity' status without the appeal of strong brands like Alfa Romeo or Maserati.

He added that the success of Alfa Romeo's renaissance, which he said remained in the "nursery" phase, was crucial to the technical credibility of Maserati going forward.

New Jeep Wrangler lands with hybrid engine and big tech boost

One element of FCA that's likely to be divested from the group, however, is automotive components supplier Magneti Marelli, with a sale to FCA shareholders possible by the end of the year, according to Marchionne.

More generally, the charismatic CEO restated his reluctance to make the kind of ambitious pronouncements on EVs and driverless cars that have been made by competitors such as Ford, General Motors and   Nissan.

He said that hybrids and EVs will inevitably become 'mandatory' in a post-Dieselgate Europe, though, due to the stringent punishments that car makers will face for missing fleet-average CO2 emissions targets.

"We will remain technology-neutral to meet regulatory demands," Marchionne said, noting that diesel still had its place in meeting emissions goals. "I don't know anyone who's making money out of selling electric vehicles and I don't think we've answered the CO2 issue with electric. We need to be realistic about what's going on. It will eventually go in that direction, it will just take a lot longer than people think. [Talk of] electrification is not outlandish, but it's premature."

By 1 Junethis year -which will mark the 14thanniversary of Marchionne taking charge of Fiat and eight years in charge of the unified FCA -the group expects to be debt-free and its plan for the years to 2022 will be announced. Soon after, the FCA board will reveal the identity of his successor.

Graham Heeps

urn:contentItem:5C6T-TVD1-DXH2-638C-00000-00Fidelity National Financial, Inc. at Barclays Americas Select Conference - Final2014-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:39ZLexisNexis051314a5370671.771Fidelity National Financial, Inc.at Barclays Americas Select Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Brent Bickett

Fidelity National Financial, Inc.- President

* Tony Park

Fidelity National Financial, Inc.- CFO

* Dan Murphy

Fidelity National Financial, Inc.- EVP Director of IR

Conference Call Participants

* Mark DeVries

Barclay's - Analyst

Presentation

MARK DEVRIES, ANALYST, BARCLAY'S: For those of you who don't know, I'm Mark DeVries, the Consumer Finance analyst at Barclay's -- very pleased to have the team from Fidelity National Financialwith us today. Presenting will be Brent Bickett. For those of you who aren't familiar, he's been part of the FNF family for a long time running the M&A business, both FNF and FIS. He's now the President of FNF. I'm also joined by Tony Park, the CFO, and we've got Dan Murphy in the back of the room.

FNF was our top pick going into the year. It's been a pretty strong performer despite significant headwinds in the mortgage origination business. I think, in large part, one, because the stock has been cheap, but also because there's a lot of positive aspects to the story, particularly the acquisition of LPS, the synergies they're realizing there and also the spinoff of noncore assets, which I'm sure they'll get into in great detail.

With that, I'm going to hand it off.

BRENT BICKETT, PRESIDENT, FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL, INC.: -- Thank you, appreciate it. I also appreciate all of you being here. It's always fun to come overseas to see people who want to invest in a US-centric company. But we think we have a very interesting story for you and are very excited to tell it.

So here's the overview of our company. As was alluded to, we have, really, two businesses. What we're calling our core business is our title insurance and then our real estate settlement services business and then our technology businesses. Again, we're the number-one franchise for title insurance and then real estate settlement services in the country. And that's what we're now calling our core business.

In January, we announced that we're going to form a tracking stock. We have a series of investments, the aggregate, about US$1.35 billion worth of value that we're going to basically give to our shareholders in the form of a stock distribution of an entity -- well, it's not really an entity, it's really just a -- you'll be publicly traded shares that track the performance of these underlying investments.

Now, we made that decision because there's substantial value in these investments, and I'll talk about them a little bit more at length later on, that wasn't, we felt, fully reflected in our share price. And subsequent to the announcement, our stock price did, in fact, advance and go forward. It's about $4.71 a share of value. That's on our books, that's not necessarily fair market value. And when we get to that point of the presentation, I will kind of give you some indications of where potential fair market value might be for that business.

We were favorable with the SEC. We got through the SEC without a review, so we're going to be 90 days sooner than our projected timeline. The shareholder vote for the tracking stock is in June, and then assuming we get affirmation from our shareholders, we'll distribute the shares of FNFV, which will be a ticker symbol shortly thereafter.

Important is, in a post-tracker world, if you own a share of FNF, you will just own our core business, which is, again, the market-leading franchise for processing real estate transactions and mortgages in the United States. If you then own FNFV you'll realize the benefit as we monetize these investments that we have and, again, I'll give you more color on that later on. You'll get the benefit of that.

Future cash flows that we generate, and we're moving into an interesting cycle for FNF as our cash flow should start accelerating over the next several years as our claims paid over prior-year policies, particularly in the mid-2000s, like 2005, 2006, 2007, and 2008. As those tail off, we'll start generating a lot more free cash flow. All the free cash flows that we generate on a go-forward basis will be invested in our core business. What I mean by investing -- repaying debt, paying dividends, buying other core assets to complement what we have, and potentially repurchasing shares.

Our organizational structure -- Bill Foley is our Chairman and CEO. He's also the founder of the Company. I report to him. We have our CEO, Randy Quirk. Randy's functional responsibilities are running our title business. We are organized in three functional groups -- our Fidelity National Title Group, and we have -- Roger Jewkes runs the left, Erica runs our agency operations, and Mike Nolan runs the East, all reporting up to Randy.

Black Knight Holdings, I'll get in more detail on what that business is. The Technology side is run by a gentleman named Tom Sanzone, a new manager. We replaced, in the LPS transaction, the former senior management of that business, so now Tom runs it. And then Chris Azur runs what we call our ServiceLink business. Both of those report up to Randy.

We have shared services, so we try to -- we're very cost-efficient. Tony runs all of our financial operations, Peter Sadowski runs all of our legal and claims. Then on the corporate side, contracts and things like that, Mike Gravelle runs it.

As was mentioned, I'm President of the Company. My functional responsibilities are all strategic investments, corporate strategy, mergers and acquisitions, and I've been doing that for more than 15 years. And I also oversee every one of the portfolio Company investments.

Black Knight -- in January we closed on the purchase of LPS as a $3.4 billion transaction. We funded that with $2.5 billion in cash and 26 million shares of FNF. For those of us that followed us, we originally targeted $100 million in cost synergies. We increased that target to $225 million in February and further increased it to $290 million when we had our earnings call late in April.

For those, again, that know us, we're very experienced acquirers of businesses. We've done that our whole corporate life, and we are very good about getting cost synergies. We make the decisions early, we closed in January, we're largely done in terms of the integration. So now we could focus going forward and then growing the revenue base. The margins, obviously, will be flowing through in Q2, Q3 as we realize the benefits of those synergies.

Why did we buy it? Well, interestingly, we used to own LPS back in the day. I ran mergers and acquisitions for them back in 2000 -- when we formed it back in 2000. It was part of a big tech processor called FIS, so as some of you might know, it's the largest [Sintec] processor in the world. And then we spun FIS out of FNF back in 2006. They then spun LPS out of it in 2008, and then we repurchased it back in 2014. So I know we know the business well.

Why did we buy it? They have some core assets in the real estate and mortgage business that we think are critical to how we sell our core title insurance and real estate settlement service products. They have a mortgage servicing platform that processes over 55% of the US mortgages, and it's very recurring revenue, which we need, because we're in a cyclical business in our core. We get paid per loan per month.

But, more than that, we are a trusted vendor. We're running a mission-critical system on behalf of our banking clients. They can't get rid of it. It is a heart-and-lung transplant to deconvert off the system but enables us to have conversations at a much different level than any of our competitors. We're talking to the CEO, the Risk Compliance Officer, the head of legal, a completely different level than our competitors are.

So when we start trying to cross-sell, it's important to have the relationships at the top of the house as well as the strong relationships that we had lower in the organization.

We also have a leading loan origination system, and we think that there is some systemic demand for loan originators in the United States to update their system. Many of them are custom, many of them are non-compliant with current rules and regulations. We have an industry-standard platform that is compliant. We have the alphabet soup of the regulatory bodies including the FFIEC, the CFPB, the OCC -- they all come through and vet our systems, and we welcome that because, again, that differentiates us from the competition.

FNF highlights -- as I mentioned, we're the largest provider of title insurance, technology, and transaction services to the real estate and mortgage industries in the United States. We do have some business in Canada. We're the nation's largest title insurance company, about 35% national market share. We are the dominant provider of mortgage loan origination and servicing technologies, we are also the largest provider of centralized mortgage settlement services.

That's where, typically, the large lenders in the United States where they are able to control the orders, like, typically, on refinance transactions, that they can control who they use their settlement service. We have a special group that targets those folks. And we have now, particularly with the former LPS business, we renamed it Black Knight. We now have a good mix of cyclical encounter, cyclical services business.

The real estate market in the US is still recovering, but if you look at our performance in 2011, 2012, 2013, it has been very strong despite a sluggish market. The first quarter had more seasonal noise than we've experienced in years. Last year, in Q1 of 2013, there were still a lot of federal programs like HARP and HAMP trying to help homeowners that are under water on their mortgages, and the refinancing market was still real strong.

In the first quarter of 2014, those volumes dropped off significantly -- about 70% on those on that re-fi-heavy segment. But the purchase market is remaining strong, and we're experiencing more. March was better than February, and January/April was about like March. So we're starting to get into a more normalized segment.

Our balance sheet is strong. We have a very nice cash dividend that we can easily pay. We have a collection of businesses that generates lots of cash so we could repay debt and continue our dividend. We have enough money to make further investments to complement what we just bought in terms of LPS. And, if appropriate, we should have enough funds down the road to consider repurchasing shares, if that warrants.

And for those of us that have noticed for a long time, we're very shareholder-friendly. That's my largest holding that I have personally, is shares of FNF, and it's been very lucrative to own those shares over the many years.

Going into our core business -- again, we have two segments that's our title group. We have four main underwriters on the left-hand side. It's Fidelity National Title, Chicago Title, Commonwealth, and Alamo. In almost every market, we hold either a number-one or number-two position. If we're number-two, we're number-two by not much. It's run like a machine. We have the best-in-class management. Our margins are typically significantly higher than all of our competitors and only one competitor is a close second, and it's not even that close in terms of our margin capability.

It's not an easy business to manage. It's very cyclical, and we're very metric-driven, and we'll get into that a little bit more. On the right-hand side of the page, we have what we're calling Black Knight Holdings, with two businesses -- Black Knight Financial Services, that's the technology arm that I described earlier that has the number-one mortgage servicing system, and then it also has what we think is a leading loan-origination system. And then ServiceLink, which is our leading provider of mortgage processing services, default solutions and centralized settlement services. This is our core business.

This is a list of our product offerings. Basically, if you look at the real estate lifecycle, we try to fill in every product and services that can be possibly consumed when a mortgages originator or when a real estate transaction in the United States is originated. That includes the title insurance businesses, it includes the technology assets that I mentioned in terms of loan origination technology, mortgage servicing technology assets, default management assets. We have a data and analytics business, and that's a potential area of substantial growth for us. We didn't have that before we picked that up in the LPS acquisition. We have lots of customers that we could sell that. That's going to be an important revenue growth area for us.

And then down at the bottom is transaction services, which -- if you look at us versus all of our competitors, we clearly check more boxes. But that's not to say that we continually -- what we have as our strength is customer relationships, so we keep trying to find more products that we could deliver to those customers. Our customers, typically, are larger institutions, and so if there's complementary things that we could get that brings us smaller clients, we'll look at those as well. But we have the most rounded product offering of any of our competitor set.

What's our operating strategy? It's to extend and leverage our technology-enabled solutions in the real estate industry. We believe that we have terrific growth opportunities in our real estate transaction services, so we look at what our share of wallet is at Wells Fargo. If we're not getting enough appraisal business, we push to get more appraisal business. If we're weak in a product area, we have the relationships to push to try to get more business. So it's getting greater share of wallet across that spectrum.

As I mentioned on the loan technology -- origination technology solutions, there's, we think, systemic demand. These people need a change, and we have a great solution that, really, nobody else has, particularly when you link it with our servicing platform, which nobody else has.

We'll continue to run the default management. There's always going to be defaults. Obviously, those are trended down as the wave of defaults have stabilized, but there's still always people that have issues, and loans will always -- a small segment of them -- will always have issues, and we have products and services to manage them on behalf of our clients. And then the data and analytics, again, we think that's a big growth area for us.

We've already taken out the cost, now it's really pursuing growth initiatives, and we're looking to -- we are a cyclical business in our core title insurance. We need a real estate transaction to happen, and that's when all of our products and services kick in and, importantly, it doesn't matter if it's a refinance transaction, a resell of a residential property or commercial. It doesn't matter if you pay cash. 40% of the market in the first quarter was cash transactions in the United States. Our products will kick in even under those conditions.

So we want to pursue growth initiatives, get more recurring revenue so we can make it a little bit more predictable so when you guys look at our stock, we could give you a little bit more visibility into the power of cash flow that we can generate.

We want to bring to market new innovative solutions. I mean, we already have mapped out the whole mortgage lifecycle, and now that we have LPS back in the fold, this has given us a lot more opportunities to create new solutions that the market needs. And, really, a good example of that is sort of in the servicing area where our servicing platform, we think, when you look at a Wells Fargo, who is one of our big clients, we might have 20% of their technology spend in the servicing side.

Well, what's the other 80%? The other 80% is the 300 custom systems that they have surrounding our servicing platform. So we could target and make modules that are fully integrated into MSP, we can get a greater share of wallet. When we do those, what we'll do is work with -- and we are working with Wells Fargo, and identify each one. So they're our beta client. Once we implement it for them, then we could roll it out to all of our other 100 MSP clients.

We want to expand customer relationships in its cross-sell. I mean, again, our greatest strength are customer relationships, sell more to them. And we're best-in-class at aggressively managing our costs, and our management team in the title side and manage the cyclical business better than anybody else in our industry.

Looking at the market share overview -- on the bottom, I'll go there first -- we have 35% national market share, but if you take a closer look at that, we conduct our business in two fashion -- one is what we call direct. This is where it's our office. We have over 1,200 of them across the United States, and it's our people so we pay -- on every dollar of premium, we get to keep the dollar. But then we pay our people costs, we pay our real estate leasing costs and other variable costs, but it's a more profitable segment for us because, on a gross basis, we get more cash per dollar on our direct share.

And, importantly, if you look at our number-two which is First American, we're 60% larger than them on the direct side.

(dial tone)

That enables us when purchases come back up, that's where we'll benefit more from having a larger footprint to capture the resale transactions, and our customers there are realtors. And so as the purchase market -- if you're bullish on the purchase market stabilizing and growing in the US, we're going to derive more benefit from that than our competition.

(telephone dialing)

Also, it helps on small commercial because we do have national commercial centers that handle hotels and office buildings and significant properties, but there's a lot of smaller commercial three-unit apartment buildings -- that's commercial -- and those flow through our local operations. So it's a very key competitive advantage, and it's very, very expensive for competitors to -- there's nothing [Stewart] can do to really move their market share into (inaudible).

(presentation interrupted by background noise)

First American can, maybe by acquisition, but it's very tough to move market share under direct site. Easier would be the agency site on the right. We have 28% market share in agency. However, in that situation, for every dollar of premium, the agent keeps, on average, $0.80. To us, they keep $0.75 because we aggressively manage the splits better than our competitors. So we're working with $0.24 dollars upon which we pay premium tax of $0.02 on the dollar, and we pay -- set up a loss reserve. We have G&A, and then the rest is gross margin.

So on a gross margin basis, actually not so bad, but on a gross dollar basis, we'd rather have $1.00 of direct revenue. And then on a combined basis, we have 35% market share.

As I mentioned, we're either number-one or number-two across the country. We're number-one in every important state that we'd like to be. In those areas, where we're number-two, we're number-two by -- I think First American in Arizona, which is 31 -- I'm not sure if you know your geography in the United States, but they're at 32, we're at 31. In Nevada, they're at 36, we're at 35. So it's neck-and-neck. And then where we're number-one, we're typically number-one by a long, long margin.

And, as I mentioned, our title team is the best in the business. It is a tough business, and we are very metric-driven. We look at our inventory -- we're not worried. We're trying to project, and a lot of people have asked us today, well, where do you think originations are going to go? Where do you think purchase -- our crystal ball is really no clearer than anybody else. But we don't have our managers worry about something that they can't control.

We look at our current inventories, we look at our staffing, we look at our metrics, and it's open orders per employees, closed orders per employees, order counts, and we make changes on the fly based upon the volumes that we're seeing. We're slow to add headcount when volumes improve because we're always pessimistic that it's going to go back down again. So we'll probably do -- undo margins as volumes improve, but we're very aggressive when the counts go down. And you can imagine, when the markets drop and significantly going towards the end of last year and into this year, our team was hard at work doing what they do best, which is managing our business.

We say that we can get to a normalized pretax margin of 15% to 20%. When we use the word "normalized," we think $1.4 billion market would be great if $1 billion of it was purchase. And we could probably get to the low end of the 15%. We'd probably need that purchase market to go up a little bit higher than that to get to above 15% pretax. But it would be a very pleasant place to be. And this is nowhere near, by the way, what the markets used to be back in the early 2000s. These are still a fraction of what they were back earlier in the decade.

And this is an example of -- I mentioned that we feel that that we've -- and we do -- run the best title business. So despite the revenue slowing and moving with the market, you can see a high correlation with originations on the left-hand side and with our revenue and pretax margins on the right-hand side.

We really did ride a good wave -- as you look at 2009 and 2010, we were still reducing our cost structure from the heydays of 2006 and 2007. But then you started seeing our margins expand on the right-hand side from 6.6% in 2009 to 7.7% in 2010, getting to the double-digit of 10.9% and 11%, 14% in 2012, and then 13.7% in 2013.

If Randy Quirk, who, again, runs our title operations this year, even in this type of market, he feels that we, at minimum, we should do 10% pretax profit on our title business if not more. But we've been a very strong performer in a pretty volatile industry.

And, again, just further evidence of our ability to manage costs through origination cycles. Our biggest expense is people. And so the first thing we do is adjust staffing on our people. Our second-largest cost is our real estate costs of our footprint, harder to adjust, although we've taken advantage of reducing our footprint. I think we're up at our peak, almost 2,000 offices, consolidated down to the 1,200 that we have now. Lowering our rental rates, taking advantage of when the markets were weaker, lowering the amount of square footage that we rent. But you could see that we very, very aggressively manage headcount, which is the green bar, over the cycles, an event depending upon our order volume.

And this is our margin profile, over time, versus our competitors. As you can see in every single year, we've significantly outpaced our industry. Oftentimes, we make more pretax than the rest of the industry combined.

We're sort of an oligopoly. We're the largest player, and then in a typical oligopoly, the second tier, and then it really drops off in number 3, 4, and 5. But usually the large-scale players make the undue process, and that's our position.

We're real excited, again, about the Black Knight and ServiceLink business. I mean, this is going to be, we think, one of our biggest value drivers, going forward. We own 65% of it. We needed -- we did not have the financial strength to buy it on our own because the seller demanded more cash, and we have to maintain our investment-grade rating, so we brought in a partner to help us buy it. So we own 65% in a private equity firm on 35%.

We both have the technology side, which, again, is that mortgage servicing platform, the default processing -- well, it's the default technology platform called Desktop. Really see, in the loan origination platforms, they did just under $200 million in revenue, EBITDA margins in the mid-30s. You'll see those margins expand up into the 40s as the benefits of the cost synergies start rolling through to the balance of the year.

They have not really been fully reflected yet. We've made a lot of cost savings, but you'll start to see them in our numbers in Q2, Q3, and Q4. We think that there's terrific growth opportunities in this business. As I mentioned, there's high demand in the customer conversations that we're having about them moving off of custom expensive platforms and moving to ours is compelling. They want to reduce cost, they want to improve quality, and they want to reduce their risk -- their compliance risk. And we answer all three of those questions.

So this business is a technology business, highly, highly predictable. Our objective is to try to grow at high single digits. Again, get its EBITDA margins into the high 40s, and it's an extremely, extremely valuable asset. If you annualize it, it's around $800 million of revenue. Mid-40s EBITDA margins once the synergies are realized, and if you can growth that high single-digit, you guys probably know some companies that are like that that trade at very attractive premiums.

And then the second piece, again, is ServiceLink. It's the number-one franchise. It did $215 million in revenue in the first quarter. It's focused, though, squarely on the re-fi side. We're trying to extend its product suite into more purchase-oriented products like appraisal because even a purchase order needs an appraisal.

There's flood certificates, which is on any type of loan that's originated. We do vendor management for third-party appraisal companies for lenders that want their own appraisal, and we'll manage that on behalf of the lenders, and we get paid for that. And we're also the largest, still, default processor in the country. Even though defaults are down significantly, there's still a good market there, and we're, by far, the largest in that field.

And what's our operating strategy? I kind of touched on this already. Technology solutions that deliver value. We're in a hot spot right now. All of our customers on that side, they're under extreme and -- you're probably meeting with some of them these next few days. The banks are under a lot of regulatory duress. And we're providing solutions that are helping them out.

They also need to reduce costs. They're not making as much fee income as they used to, so our value prop to the banks is very, very compelling, and that's why we're confident about getting that mid single-digit organic revenue growth. Perhaps we can even do better.

But, again, I can't stress it enough. We had our mortgage servicing conference about a month ago, and the number-one thing we heard from all of the clients is it's unquantifiable litigation and regulatory risk. And so we're hitting them with solutions that help mitigate that problem. It's a very -- no one else has what we have, so there's no other servicing platform that can do what ours does. So we're in a very strong competitive position to continue to grow that business.

As I mentioned, on our ServiceLink side, just take more share of wallet. Our clients there are still the large banks, and the same story -- and this is kind of important for ServiceLink. If you look at the real estate settlement business in the United States, there's still lots of competitors. If you're a bank, now the regulators are forcing the banks to vet their vendors. And we want that because that trend will benefit the large providers like ourselves, and there's still -- for example, we go to Chase, they use 20 different settlement service providers, and Chris Azur, that runs this business, will talk to banks as they listen.

We have the FFIEC, the CFPB, we've been vetted as number 18, had anybody in there. What happens if there's a problem? Do they have a balance sheet that they could stand up behind the risk that they're taking? So we think, over time, this regulatory cloud is benefiting us and other large vendors because we will push that story. There is no reason why Chase should do business with 20 vendors. It's too risky for them.

The problem is is that they have a vendor manager, and if you took away all the vendors for him to manage, he'd lost a job. So that's why those relationships up at the CFO and with the head attorneys and the risk and compliance people, that's who you talk to. Then they force down the decisions to reduce the 18 to 20 that Chase is using, down to three. And we would pick up more share of wallet in that regard.

We are best-in-class. I mean, if you talk to any of our customers, and you stay on this settlement service side, they will say ServiceLink, when we get our surveys back, we think that we're number one, and our clients would say that we're number-one.

We're the only ones, too, that really try to mix in the technology assets with our products. And a lot of our competitors don't have those technology assets. For example, when we sell a loan origination platform to one of our clients, we'll embed [releasee]. Releasee is this electronic hub that connects all the lenders to all of these settlement service providers, including ourselves, but we get a click fee. Every time a lender orders any settlement service that was on the network, we get a fee. So we'll make sure that our LOS system has that attached to it.

We also make sure that it's easy to order our product. It's right into their workflow system. So if they want to order a Fidelity product, they just click -- boom -- it's in their workflow. If they want to order somebody else, that's fine, but it might be a little bit harder to order somebody else's. That's the advantage of having the technology and embedding your products into that technology.

This is a very volatile business because of the re-fi oriented. So, again, we always push our managers to monitor their operating metrics to reduce staff and do what they can in volatile markets, and particularly this segment of the market was down 70% Q1'13 to Q1'14, yet we still made a profit. Most competitors in that division, they lost a lot of money. And you'll see the benefits of the synergies start really flowing through in Q2 and Q3.

US real estate market overview -- I'm not predicting anything. Existing home sales -- this is just all factual stuff. We're at about 5.1 million existing home sales in 2013. Certainly, substantially lower than what happened at the peak. Right now, as we look at headwinds for that business in 2014, lending standards are tough. I mean, the banks are being forced to make loans to strong credit-quality borrowers.

Well, as you can appreciate, not everybody has strong credit. So we need credit standards to loosen and, historically, they do. Other headwinds is their inventory, on the right-hand side of this page. It's at 1.9 million units. That's historically low. We need more people to put their homes on the market. So when you have low inventory, you will experience in certain markets spikes and prices, simple supply and demand. So we need more inventory out there.

But, typically, prices then will lead to more inventory, and then we think the federal government, typically, is very friendly to US consumers on buying houses. So we need credit standards to ease, and then that should be the catalyst then to get the 5.1 million units of something substantially higher.

Now, interestingly, at the bottom half of the page, in 2013, 2012 we experienced a market that was 70% refinanced and 30% purchased. So 70% of the market was people just getting a lower rate and refinancing their mortgages; 30% was people buying a newer existing home.

Our average fee per file was about $1,300 because we make about $1,000 per refinance transaction and about $2,000, on average, on a purchase deal. If you flip to the right-hand side of the page, we think the markets now move to more of a 70% purchase market, 30% re-fi, just given the bump-up in rates. But our fee per file, on a blended basis, using the same math, would increase with 1,300 to 1,700. So we could withstand a drop yet still make very good margins because we're getting more fee-per-file. And you saw that in the first quarter versus our fee-per-file was substantially higher in our first quarter of 2014 versus the prior year. So we could withstand some drop-off in the mortgage market and still make good money.

And we don't have a cost accounting system, but we make more raw dollars on $2,000 per order even though there's more labor associated with processing a purchase order, it's more money in our pocket versus a refinance on an order-by-order basis.

Now talking about our tracking stock. Again, these shares will be distributed to FNF shareholders following an affirmative vote at the end of June. If you own these shares, you will get the value of our noncore investments, what we call our "portfolio company" investments. And at the time of distribution, it will be about -- our book value is $1.350 billion, about $4.72 per share.

That is not fair market value, and I'll give you some more detail on that in a second. We said that for every three shares of FNF you own, you'll get one share of the tracker. So the share price will be closer to -- just south of 15, so 3x $4.72 if it trades near our book value. The only other difference is that we'll still manage these businesses the same way that we do today. It's not a separate company, so I'll still oversee, on a day-to-day basis, the performance of the business. It still reports up to our Board of Directors.

We're not going to experience any incremental costs other than some modest accounting, because we'll have separate supplemental financial statements for our core business, FNF, and then for FNFV. So there will be a little bit more accounting going on. We'll have our consolidated statements, which won't be relevant anymore. We'll have FNF, which will be relevant for our core investors and FNFV, which will be relevant for the FNFV investors.

When we have shareholder votes, they're going to treat -- basically, we're issuing, like, 90 new million shares, but when we vote on Board of Directors, on anything that shareholders have the right to vote on, all those shares will be aggregated. So FNFV shareholders will vote on matters affecting all of FNF.

What's our strategy? We believe, as we look at our history and what we've been able to do, we've -- under Bill Foley's leadership, we grew from, really, nothing to be the largest title insurance company in the country. We grew a company called FIS, which is publicly traded, to be the largest Sintec processor in the world. Its enterprise value is over $20 billion.

We know how to build businesses, and what we're good at is finding good management, putting money behind good management, and aggressively growing businesses. So what do we do with these portfolio company investments? We try to take significant ownership stake. So we sit on the Board, we help direct strategy, we make sure that the leadership is doing the right thing. If not, we'll change leadership. We direct M&A strategies, and then we'll direct disposition strategies.

Operations -- we just use our track record. I mean, we do view that we're good drivers of business, so we try to leverage our operational expertise. We have a lot of talent in our business. When we find a new company, I'll bring in our key ops guys that are relevant for that business and make sure, particularly on the cost side, that their accounting is in order, their legal is in order, their IT infrastructure is in order, and et cetera.

Governance -- we're on the Board, and we help direct that strategy. And then monetization, we've done almost every transaction that you can imagine -- spinoffs, splitoffs, recaps. We know how to properly dispose of businesses. We could take them public, we could spin them out, and all of those strategies are still available to us to get the most for our shareholders.

Here is a quick overview of some of the companies in our -- that are in our portfolio. We have Remy, which is an auto -- starters and alternators, electronic motors, hybrid motors company. It deals both in the aftermarket space. So if you have an older car, and it needs a new starter and alternator, we sell those.

On the OEM side, the big clients are General Motors, Hyundai. On the heavy-duty side, Caterpillar, et cetera. It's a great company, publicly traded. It's on our books for $19.25 a share. It's publicly traded right now, and it's at over $24 a share. We have 16.3 million shares. So the difference between what it's currently trading at, what it's on our books. You can kind of do that math there. It's actually -- it's doing well. We feel that this is the most mature investment and probably be the first that we've looked at to figure out the right strategy to monetize.

The second company I'll highlight is American Blue Ribbon Holdings. It's about $1.2 billion of revenue. We have it on our books right now for about $150 million, and it's really about 4x EBITDA. Comparable companies trade between 8x to 11x EBITDA. So, clearly, what we have it on the books, fair market value would suggest there's a lot of upside there. It trades in the casual and family dining segments -- 640 restaurants, great management led by [Hawson Lewis]. This guy is incredible.

We -- originally, it was a $400 million revenue business. We bought two other companies. This guy is just one of the best operators that we've seen. And, again, when we find good operators, we know how rare they are, we'll put money behind them and help them grow their businesses. This one, we think, would be a good candidate to take public.

On the J. Alexander side, it's more upscale dining. It's on our books for about $100 million, 6x EBITDA, comparable companies trade at double that.

Digital Insurance is on our books for $130 million. It's about 8x EBITDA, comparable companies are kind of in the 12x range. It's the nation's leading employee benefits brokerage company, so helping employers manage through the health care stuff and provide plans. We bought it at a perfect time. There was a lot of noise surrounding Obamacare, the American Affordability Care Act, and we bought it at a very attractive price, and this one has terrific growth opportunities.

Two other ones that we have on our books are Ceridian and ComData. Ceridian is a payroll processing company. It also has a very attractive workforce management software, and it helps -- it's called Dayforce, and it helps -- not only does it do payroll, but it also schedules employees to be most cost-efficient given the nature of business that the company uses it for.

ComData is a payments processor. It is a jewel of a company. It's in the long haul trucking industry in the United States, but it's one of the largest prepaid companies, corporate payments companies, and then in the long haul segment they have all the -- substantially, all of the long haul companies -- the truckers and the truck stops, and it's like an ecosystem with a payments card that tracks -- they use it for fuel, they use it for their salaries, they use it for their per diem. All the information is reloaded into the trucking company's accounting systems to track. It's a terrific, terrific company. It's on our books for $331 million, which is about on the aggregate. Both these companies combined, about 10x EBITDA.

EDP Paychex on the payroll side, and some softwares of service, workforce companies, they trade between 12x to 20x. And that Dayforce business is growing like a weed.

And then on the payment side, again, there's Fleetcorp, Wright Express, and they trade at 12x to 20x EBITDA, too. So we think we have some room for some nice value creation opportunity there.

And, with that, I'll turn it over to Tony to quickly go over the financial highlights.

TONY PARK, CFO, FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL, INC.: Thanks, Brent. I don't know how much time I have. I don't think I have a lot, so I'll go quickly.

Consolidated financial highlights -- you can see a three-year trend here -- $4.8 billion back in 2011, grew to $7.2 billion in 2012, and $8.6 billion in 2013. Clearly, a nice trajectory there. A big part of that, though, relates to the consolidation of Remy and the Restaurant Group that Brent mentioned. We consolidated the Restaurant Group in the early part of 2012 when we took a controlling interest in ABRH, and then later that year in August of 2012, when we took a controlling interest in Remy, we consolidated that business. So that's why you see a large jump in revenue in other revenue and also in pretax earnings we had about $200 million in pretax gains associated with the consolidation of those two businesses.

Let me jump over to FNF core business for a moment and, again, core is separate from FNFV. Our core business represents our title business as well as our Black Knight business and our ServiceLink business, and ServiceLink is combined within our title segment in our financials.

And, again, you can see a nice growth trajectory in the core segment. We don't -- we acquired LPS in January of 2014, so those results aren't in any of the prior-year periods. But if you look at the adjusted EBITDA, you see $179 million in the first quarter of 2013 up against $148 million in the first quarter of 2014.

Pretax earnings, you see a big negative of $100 million and, really, that reflects a lot of merger-related items that we incurred in the first quarter as we closed the LPS transaction, including merger costs of about $41 million, severance expenses of about $39 million, synergy bonus accrual of $32 million, and purchase price amortization of $75 million. That's why you see adjusted earnings are far different than what we show on our reported basis. Adjusted net earnings were $74 million, or $0.26 per share.

FNFV revenue -- you see it jump from $18 million in 2011. We consolidated those businesses in 2012, so that jumped up to $1.5 billion in 2012 and then the full year is reflected in 2013, $2.6 billion in total revenue.

On an adjusted EBITDA basis, we have $58 million in the first quarter of 2014. The difference between our adjusted net earnings of $10 million and our GAAP net earnings of a $16 million loss relates to a settlement at ComData. There was a litigation case settled in that business, and we took a hit on that one-time settlement.

Turning quickly to the balance sheet, we have total assets in our core business of $12.1 billion after the acquisition of LPS, total liabilities of $6.9 billion, equity including non-controlling interests of $5.2 billion. You can see debt in our core segment is at $3 billion, which reflects the borrowing that we had of about $2 billion for the acquisition of LPS.

And then, finally, just to recap the highlights that Brent touched on -- we are the largest provider of title insurance, technology and transaction services to the real estate and mortgage industries. We have a 35% market share in the title business with leading margins. We're the biggest in loan origination and servicing technology solutions as well as data and analytics.

Through ServiceLink, we're the largest centralized mortgage settlement services provider, and we do have a mix of both cyclical and counter-cyclical real estate businesses. We've demonstrated over many years a very strong performance especially in times when they're very difficult. That's when we do our best work.

We've talked about this is a clear way -- FNF is a clear way to benefit from an investment in a recovering real estate market. We're in every market, residential purchase, residential refinance, commercial purchase, commercial refinance, direct agency, default, and loan growth. So we feel like it's a great place to participate in that recovery.

And, as Brent mentioned, we have a track record of creating significant value for shareholders over a long period of time.

Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5NHW-DD41-JCDN-132N-00000-00Fidelity star stock pickers exit positions in Buffalo Wild Wings2017-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:39ZLexisNexisBUSINESSFidelity star stock pickers exit positions in Buffalo Wild Wings

BOSTON: Two star stock pickers at Fidelity Investments exited their positions in Buffalo Wild Wings during the first quarter, as the restaurant chain faces pressure from an activist investor pushing to oust its chief executive. Boston-based Fidelity owned about 4 percent of Buffalo Wild Wings' stock at the end of March, down from 15 percent three months earlier, according to a regulatory filing made late Thursday. Fidelity portfolio managers Steven Wymer and Gavin Baker, currently crushing rival managers returns with big tech stock bets, led the way as the mutual fund giant sold 1.85 million shares in Buffalo Wild Wings during the first quarter.

Activist hedge fund Marcato Capital Management, which owns 6 percent of Buffalo Wild Wings, has been courting big shareholders as it seeks to replace the company's chief executive officer, Sally Smith, and win board seats. Wymer's US$36 billion Fidelity Growth Company Fund owned no Buffalo Wild Wings shares at the end of March, according to the regulatory filing. At the end of February, the fund owned 368,831 shares; it had reported owning 600,000 shares at the end of 2016. The fund's year-to-date total return of 15.75 percent is double the S&P 500's 7.74 percent gain, according to Morningstar Inc data, as of Thursday. Wymer has beat 83 percent of his peers during that period. Baker's US$14.8 billion Fidelity OTC Portfolio also held no Buffalo Wild Wings shares at the end of March, the filing shows. At the end of 2016, the fund owned 255,600 shares. The OTC Portfolio's year-to-date total return of 19.78 percent is beating 99 percent of actively managed large-cap growth funds. A Fidelity spokesman declined to comment. Marcato last month ratcheted up the pressure on Buffalo Wild Wings by calling on Smith, who's held the top job since 1996, to retire and urging fellow shareholders to vote for its slate of four directors at the June 2 annual meeting. The hedge fund wants management to franchise more of its stores, increase sales and raise profit margins. Buffalo Wild Wings' shares traded at US$156.30 on Friday afternoon, up 1 percent for the year-to-date. Marcato has said that the share price could top US$400 in the next four years if its plans for improvement are implemented. Not all Fidelity managers have a negative view. Patrick Venanzi's US$2.9 billion Small Cap Growth Fund built a new position of 205,200 shares during the first quarter. Buffalo Wild Wings accounted for 1.2 percent of the fund's assets. (Reporting by Svea Herbst-Bayliss and Tim McLaughlin; Editing by Leslie Adler) - Reuters
