DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: The LIBOR scandal costs Barclays Chairman Marcus Agius his job and put CEO Bob Dimon in the sites of politicians. He suspects this Dimon has lost its sparkle. And to heat other banks worldwide.

The heat coming down on bankers around the world but nothing is compared to the scorcher blistering parts of the United States and triggering deadly storms. Millions waking up this morning without electricity and temperatures in some places are over 100 degrees.

The Chinese economy anything but hot and continues to cool down. The latest PMI reading indicates that factory production and exports continues to plunge as investors wonder what happens when the world global engine begins to stall.

And what's old is new again in Mexico where voters hand power to the political party that ruled for 70 years but was swept from office more than a decade ago only to return on this Monday, July the 2nd, 2012.

Good morning, everybody. Well, I'm back from vacation. Connell is not here. He runs for the hills when he knows he has to be with me. I'm Dagen McDowell everybody. This is BEST OF IMUS.

And we've got some incredible interviews that the I-man did recently. Coming up this hour, Jose Rodriguez. And also Imus on Imus, not blonde on blonde. Deirdre, Imus and Wyatt Imus go head to head. I missed that last week and I cannot wait to see that.

Meantime, let's bring you up to date on what is happening in the global markets. And first, we start with Asia. The Hong Kong market was closed for a holiday today. And we had some mixed reaction there. Again, that reading on Chinese factory activity did come in better than expected, somewhat better than expected. The Nikkei was lower, one with the Kospi and South Korea. But the Shanghai managed to tick up just a bit. But the ASX 200 index was also higher.

We have gains across the board, potentially we follow a reaction to what happened with European leaders and the changes in that bailout facility to help Italy and Spain. We'll see if that lasts. Coming up, we'll talk to a guest from Europe, from London.

Let's take a look at the futures here in the U.S. It looks like a positive start. Again, the markets closed early tomorrow. Off on Wednesday. Very busy week for data with that critical jobs report coming out on Friday. And we have essentially flat lines there. Not flat but down. Oil and gold with gold falling almost one percent. Oil is down two percent this morning.

For more on the European markets, let's go live to London where we're joined by Jane Foley, senior foreign currency strategist for Rabobank. Jane, how long does the euphoria from that deal struck by European leaders last? Do you think that we can even get a couple more days out of this in terms of gains?

JANE FOLEY, RABOBANK SENIOR CURRENCY STRATEGIST: Well, that's really the big question and that will be the question that prevail over the next few weeks. It is quite likely that we'll get decent support from this over the next few weeks, perhaps over the next few months. But I think as we've already been seen, there was already some skepticism entering in here and there's still a lot of pit holes thrown up by what was agreed last week. And a lot of uncertainty about the details too.

You've already mentioned the banking supervisions. How long is it going to take for Europe to get a single banking supervisor? And what exactly, what should have shaken this at going to be? And there's also about the ESM too. There's been some complaints in some European countries about the seniority the announcement last week, that the ESM would not be seen here to -- holders of Spanish government debt. So, again some confusion today and therefore some backtracking. More consultative tone I think we should say in some markets in Europe this morning.

MCDOWELL: What is the next great hurdle for the European markets? What is the next meeting, piece of news that you were looking to that we can count on -- give us some direction in these markets?

FOLEY: Well, of course, we do have the ECB policy meeting on Thursday. Many people expecting a rate cut there because of course the very slow growth conditions in Europe. Beyond that, we have a finance ministers meeting on July the ninth. But that will be important because the market is expecting more detail about the purchase that were announced last week.

MCDOWELL: What also is the reaction to the resignation to the chairman of Barclays, the livewire scandal there, what it means for other banks not just in Europe but around the globe?

FOLEY: Well, of course, Barclays is one of the first banks to come through and pay the fine and be fully investigated in the scandal. But I think many people in many parts of the world are waiting for what else is going to come. And there could be further bad news ahead.

MCDOWELL: Jane, thank you so much. Jane Foley, senior foreign currency strategist for Rabobank.

Let's take a closer look at the Asian markets. And for that, we go to FOX Business contributor Katie Sargent. She joins us on the phone from Singapore. Hey, Katie, reaction to that factory report from China.

KATIE SARGENT, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: That seems to be something that's taking the markets, taking the wind out of the market sails today, Dagen. Most of the markets in the region started the day pretty strong, still kind of riding that wave of euphoria on the agreement from last week over the European banks. But that quickly waned when we started looking at PMI numbers.

We saw more evidence of a slowdown in China over the weekend. The official Purchasing Managers Index for June came out showing a drop from May. It was better than expected but still showed a drop. And there was a private PMI report released today that also showed activities shrank in June. They are a little bit in disagreement over the final number but both are showing a slowdown.

So, the session started quite positive for the region. Australia's benchmark ASX 200 was up nearly one percent. But then as I say, things slowdown, the Nikkei in Japan hit a two-month in today high before faltering and finishing the day little changed. Not much movement in the rest of the markets either -- Dagen.

MACEDO: Thank you so much, Katie. Katie Sargent on the phone from Singapore. Thank you so much.

MCDOWELL: Now, for a closer look at the U.S. markets and a preview of how things will shape up today, we go to our very own Lauren Simonetti from the Newsroom. Good morning, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning. The fireworks were lit early on Wall Street with stellar gains for the major averages. The Dow rocketing 277 points on Friday. June, great months too with gains of at least 3.8 percent for the three major averages. This first trading day of July will be a busy one and an equally busy week. National manufacturing figures on tap. Auto sales tomorrow. And that key government jobs report for June is out on Friday.

Speaking of jobs, they are moving off of Wall Street. The trend is called near shoring. It's where big financial tightened higher and relocated workers to cities like Salt Lake, City, Utah. And Jacksonville, Florida where rent, taxes and labor all cost less.

Silicon Valley is seeing a similar exodus. That's the big tech giant find saving in other U.S. cities. And how do you read it? "Fifty Shades of Grey" laying off bookstore shelves. EL James' erotic novel became the nation's fastest selling paper back to reach one million sales.

Nelson book scan (ph) finds that it took 11 weeks to reach that mark, that was 25 weeks faster than the previous record holder, "The Vinci Code." Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Lauren, thank you so much. I will say nothing about that book since I have not read it and have no plans to read it. Now, we go to our Newsroom and Diane Macedo who has a look at more business news for you this morning. Hey, Diane.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I will say nothing about the book because my mother is watching.

(LAUGHTER)

Barclays Chairman Marcus Agius has resigned in the wake of the bank's interest rate raging scandal. Agius who has been the chairman for more than five years says, the scandal has dealt a devastating blow to Barclays' reputation. And at the buck stops with him, he will stay in the position until a succession plan is in place.

You might remember the bank was fined more than $450 million last week by a British and U.S. regulators for submitting false documents on the London interbank offered interest rate, which the rate at which banks lend unsecured funds to each other. Barclays has admitted that some of its traders attempted to manipulate that rate. Agius' resignation is seen as an attempt to take some pressure off CEO Bob Dimon who along with Agius also is facing calls to resign.

Airbus is set to unveil plans for its first U.S. factory today. The company's parent, European Aeronautic Defense and Space plans to spend $600 million to build a facility in Mobile, Alabama. Once it opens in 2015, the plant is expected to create 1,000 jobs and will reportedly produce four planes a month by 2017. The move also puts the facility on the home turf of U.S. rival Boeing which has 2700 employees in Alabama as well.

Bristol-Myers Squibb is buying diabetes drug maker Amylin Pharmaceuticals for $5.3 billion. That breakdown to $31 dollars a share, nine dollars higher. And the offer Bristol-Myers reportedly made back in March. Now, if you include debt, the deal is worth a total of $7 billion.

In addition, Bristol-Myers will enter into an alliance with British drug maker Astra Zeneca to developed and commercialize Amylin's diabetes drugs. Astra Zeneca will pay Bristol-Myers $3.4 billion in that deal, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Diane. Following attacks on 9/11, the CIA was instructed to protect Americans by any means necessary. Some of the agency's methods were later questioned but a new book by former CIA operative Jose Rodriguez defends the tactics used to fight the terrorists. Rodriguez was on recently to discuss it all with the I-man.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": Please welcome to the program Jose Rodriguez, has got a book called "The Hard Measures: How Aggressive CIA Actions after 9/11 Saved Americans Lives." Mr. Rodriguez, sits here and listening to me. Juan use vial language to try and apologize for it.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes.

IMUS: And two, scream and swear at the recorded commercials which makes me pretty much a mental patient. Anyway, first of all, good morning, Mr. Rodriguez.

JOSE RODRIGUEZ, "HARD MEASURES" AUTHOR: Thank you.

IMUS: How are you?

RODRIGUEZ: Thank you for inviting me on the show.

IMUS: I saw you on "60 Minutes." How did that go?

RODRIGUEZ: That went well. You know, it was my first time out doing this. I was a 31-year CIA veteran and clandestinity was my thing. And coming out in the open like that was a new one for me. So, far so good.

IMUS: Were you covert operations for the entire 31 years?

RODRIGUEZ: I was covert operative for 31 years.

IMUS: OK. So, were you at the University of Florida? Is that where you went to school?

RODRIGUEZ: Yes, I did.

IMUS: And you were recruited there?

RODRIGUEZ: No. I left the university and I sent an application. And it takes awhile but a couple of years later, I was recruited.

IMUS: You sent an application to the CIA?

RODRIGUEZ: Yes.

RODRIGUEZ: Why did you want do that?

RODRIGUEZ: I have lived in Latin America all my life, had traveled overseas, was interested in foreign affairs, was interested in that type of life. And, you know, I was always interested in the CIA. So, when it came to time, I was very fortunate to get recruited.

IMUS: What did you tell people you do?

RODRIGUEZ: Well, usually you know, I was assigned overseas for 17 years, so I had State Department cover, so I was a State Department official forever.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes.

IMUS: So, that's what you -- they didn't know you were in the CIA?

RODRIGUEZ: Well, you know, it's kind of a game. I think most people know who you are, you know. And then when you become chief of station, you become declared to that country.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: So, the official, the local service, knows who you are. And, you know, they can tell anybody else. So, it's one of those things that you do but it doesn't matter much. You still have to do your job.

IMUS: Now, the secrets you reveal, I guess they are, in this book and the techniques, methods and all that stuff, why did you do this? Was it a good idea or?

RODRIGUEZ: No, I did not reveal any secrets.

IMUS: OK.

RODRIGUEZ: I mean, they were already exposed. As a matter of fact, President Obama released the legal opinion that has all these techniques. He did it in 2009 against the advice of a couple of CIA directors because he was concerned that he would give away to the enemy exactly the outer limits of what was permissible under U.S. law, so.

IMUS: Permissible in terms of interrogation?

RODRIGUEZ: In terms of the law, what our law permits for how far we can go, yes, in interrogating prisoners.

IMUS: OK. And so, you decided to do the book for what reason?

RODRIGUEZ: I decided to write the book to set the record straight because to me, it is unbelievable the amount of misinformation that has been out there regarding our programs after 9/11. I wrote the book because I was the subject of a criminal investigation for three years for destroying some tapes and I never got the chance to say my side of the story.

And I wrote the book because there are a lot of people who are still caught up in investigations that are very unfair and are suffering a lot because of it, because they did what our government asked them to do.

IMUS: Yes, paramount at the top tier of misinformation, what would be the biggest misconception that the general public, people like me and others, would be embracing?

RODRIGUEZ: That the enhanced interrogation techniques were torture.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: That's the top.

IMUS: Yes, it sounds to me -- of course it's just me -- but like it could have been fun but just me, but people think -- I've got a couple of people a little while ago, one of whom thought that we never got any good information, water boarding people.

RODRIGUEZ: Tat is such --

IMUS: Nonsense.

RODRIGUEZ: Can I say crap in radio?

IMUS: Yes.

RODRIGUEZ: Because we got thousands of intelligence reports. We were able to disrupt plots. We were able to capture high-level terrorists. We were able to destroy the al-Qaeda organization that attacked us on 9/11 because of the work that we did.

IMUS: So, the people say, well, when you torture people, they'll simply tell you what they think you want to hear but --

RODRIGUEZ: Well, first of all, this is not torture.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: And second of all, we're smarter than that. You know, we have people who are world experts on al-Qaeda and actually know quite a bit about these individuals already. So, we've vetted them very closely and check it. And, you know, these people eventually come through with a lot of really good stuff.

IMUS: Of course, one of you guys are lawyers. And like lawyers, you already know the answer to the question before you ask it. You just want to see if they're willing to give it to you, so.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes, I think the key is knowledge. I mean, the key to a good interrogation is knowledge. How much knowledge do you know of the target? Because if you do, then they can't fool you.

IMUS: So, leading up to the murder of -- murder, assassination, whatever of Osama -- the killing of Osama bin Laden, what led up to that?

RODRIGUEZ: As you know, it was a ten-year effort. We started to look --

IMUS: A lot of people don't know that.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes. Well, it was a ten-year effort. We started looking for Bin Laden the day after 9/11.

IMUS: Right. Well, I guess they knew that but they didn't know that it was a concentrated effort in intelligence gathering and so on. So, walk me through that if you can.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes. Interestingly, because if you had asked me in 2002, how long it would take to get Bin Laden, I would take you 18 months, two years perhaps. Because I figured eventually, we would find him. But he took himself out of the day-to-day running of al-Qaeda, and he decided he would become the symbolic figure. So, he gave up his day-to-day duties and moved to a compound in Pakistan and communicated with al-Qaeda central via courier.

And the courier would go by every two or three months to deliver messages from him to the principals of the organization. So until we found the courier, we would not be able to find Bin Laden. And finding the courier took a long time because it's one person. And we started to get some information in 2004 about the courier. We got the pseudonym of the courier...

IMUS: How did you get that? Through enhance interrogation.

RODRIGUEZ: We got that from interrogating at one of our black sites, a facilitator that we had captured.

IMUS: What is a black site?

RODRIGUEZ: A black site is the location where we would take this terrorist to, to interrogate.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: And it was a secure location. It was secure and secret, and we hid in plain sight in different parts of the world so that we could have total access, unrestricted access that we controlled to the detainee.

IMUS: Were you all at the agency and you and everybody, were you surprised that you turned up in Pakistan?

RODRIGUEZ: No. We always thought he was in Pakistan. So, I'm not surprised.

IMUS: Yes. Were you surprised that -- it seemed like a relatively easy -- I mean once they decided to go ahead and storm the compound, it seemed like a fairly easy operation. Maybe I'm just na[ve or --

RODRIGUEZ: No, I think, you know, we got the best Special Forces in the world, and I'm sure that they do this and do it very well. So, I think that once, you know, the hardest part is to find the guy, in my view. I think that once you have the target, our special operators can plan it and with the precision and the fire power and their skill, you know, I don't think there's anybody better in the world.

IMUS: So, what impact on the whole global terror operation did killing him have?

RODRIGUEZ: He was a symbolic figure. As I said before, he was not running operations day to day. He was sending pronouncements, I would like to attack America. I would like to, you know, do this and the other. But he had no direct impact on the day-to-day planning of operations, but he was still a symbolic figure and it was important to kill him.

IMUS: What did they -- did the CIA have to sign off on your book or?

RODRIGUEZ: Yes, they had to review it. You know, the manuscript is turned over to them. And they go through the publication review board. And they take some stuff out. And we know we discussed with them some things and take some things out. And agree on others. So, yes, it's a process.

IMUS: Congratulations. "60 Minutes" and all these other programs. You can't help but have a bestseller. I hope you do, so.

RODRIGUEZ: Thank you so much. Thanks for inviting me.

IMUS: By the way, thanks for your service to our country.

RODRIGUEZ: Thank you so much.

IMUS: Jose Rodriguez, "Hard Measures."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: When we come back, everybody, we'll have more news for you business and otherwise. Also, the latest on those deadly storms that devastated areas up and down the east coast leaving millions without power.

Plus, your business travelers forecast with Maria Molina who is watching this storm and the attempted recovery.

And later, it is Imus on Imus as Deirdre Imus takes on son Wyatt Imus. They battle it out on some very interesting topics.

(COMMERCIAL BREAL)

MCDOWELL: We take you around the world at a look at Asian markets. First, mixed markets there but very, very slight losses in Japan and South Korea. A slight gain on the Shanghai. But again, Hong Kong closed for holiday. Gains across the board in Europe.

Again, follow on euphoria from that European agreement, effort to bail out the banks in that country. Flat futures here in the U.S. but after those gains last week and then take a look at oil and gold. Oil, however, continued to tumble down almost two percent. I kind of like that.

And now, some of the news stories making headlines this morning. Utility crews working in blistering heat trying to restore power to hundreds of thousands along the northeast corridor. A violent storm causing damage from Indiana to New Jersey. And authorities confirming at least 13 deaths as a result.

FOX News correspondent Elizabeth Prann had the latest from Charleston,, West Virginia.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ELIZABETH PRANN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Among those killed in the severe weather, two young boys in New Jersey. They were camping and crushed by a downed tree.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: Fifty foot tall pine tree snapped. It fell on a tent that was occupied by two boys, a 7-year-old and 2-year-old.

PRANN: Powerful winds and frequent lightning whipped through the Mid- Atlantic States Friday night.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: It sounds like the fourth of July. There was a major late show, I mean, the lightning didn't stop for about 90 minutes.

PRANN: An Amtrak train traveling from New York to Chicago waylaid in West Virginia by downed trees.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: I heard the weather and heard the stuff hitting inside of the train. And next thing I know we were stopped. It was pitch- black.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: You have the power out and nothing but mountains on both sides.

PRANN: The 232 passengers eventually making it out by bus. Ohio, West Virginia, Maryland and Virginia all declared states of emergency. President Obama has reached out to the governors. Trees twisted in wires across the Washington, D.C. suburbs, crews in Virginia and Maryland trying to entangle a puzzle of power lines saying, the job requires some extra manpower.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: We requested over 1,000 crews from different parts of the country.

PRANN: Linemen working here in West Virginia in the 90-degree heat trying to restore power and relief to more than half a million customers.

(on camera) The National Weather Service calling Friday night's storm a derate (ph) show, meaning a line of thunderstorm packing damaging straight line winds some cities feeling gusts up to 90 miles per hour.

In Charleston, West Virginia, Elizabeth Prann, FOX News.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCDOWELL: Florida is now saying no to two features of President Obama's health care law. Governor Rick Scott saying, the state will not comply with the Supreme Court ruling to expand medicaid and implement insurance exchanges. Wisconsin and Louisiana to other states with republican governors also opting out of the two provisions last week. The health care law will take full effect in January 2014 but republican lawmakers are vowing to repeal it before then.

A fiesta of democracy, that is what Enrique Pena Nieto is calling his victory in Mexico's presidential election. The official preliminary count gives Pena Nieto about 38 percent of the vote. Pena Nieto is part of the institutional revolutionary party which was voted out of office in 2000 after 71 years in power. The president-elect is promising Mexicans a government that is democratic, modern and open to criticism. The PRI, the party as it's known, was long accused of ruling the country through authoritarian and corrupt practices.

And Spain does it again beating Italy four to nothing in the European championship last night. It is Spain's third straight major soccer title. Tens of thousands of fans gathering in central Madrid to see the team win. Fireworks and celebrations give temporary relief to the country's economic crisis.

Apparently, you can still play soccer if you're a broke nation. The team becomes the first to win a euro and then a world cup and then another euro. Cheers all around.

Let's go up to Diane Macedo who has a look at business news this morning. Diane, did you watch any of it?

MACEDO: I didn't actually. I didn't get a chance to. But I do love watching soccer. I heard it was a great game.

MCDOWELL: Yap. Indeed.

MACEDO: Busy working. But Facebook executives have decided to keep the company stock listed on the NASDAQ despite issues surrounding its IPO. This is according to the "Wall Street Journal" which says, the company had considered moving its shares off the NASDAQ in the days following its trading debut, but now feel that would erode confidence in the shares even further.

Facebook's executives have quietly blamed the NASDAQ for the glitches in the IPO. But officials say that -- officials at the exchange that is are working to repair the relationship. Dow is closely wrapping up its efforts to buy quest software. According to reports, the deal could be announced as early as today.

There's still no word on a final price but last week Dell offered roughly $2.3 billion for quest which offered software to help businesses manage their data bases. Dell's latest offer was better than the one made by a private equity group led by inside ventures partners which is also have been bidding on quest for the last few months. If Dell does finalizes the deal, it will mark the company's latest effort to expand beyond its core business of personal computers.

And a movie about a foul-mouthed teddy bear was the top ticket at the box office this weekend. Ted took in more than $50 million in North America beating Channing Tatum's steamy role as a male stripper in "Magic Mike." Walt Disney's animated fairy tale brave which was last week's number one fell to third place.

Tyler Perry's new film "Madea's Witness Protection" and "Madagascar 3" round out the top 5 -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: If you're going to talk about "Magic Mike," we got to role some video, I'm sorry (INAUDIBLE) at the full screen -- but just Dagen, thanks Diane.

Right now, we want to get a look at the business travelers' forecast for you. And we go to Maria Molina who is standing by in the FOX Business Weather Center. Maria, what do you know?

MARIA MOLINA, METEOROLOGIST: Hey, Dagen. And we're looking at some showers and thunderstorms still rolling through portions of the Carolinas, Georgia, the State of Alabama and also the Florida panhandle but nothing like what we saw last night or in the overnight hours when we saw over 800 reports of severe weather, a lot of them coming from this region where we're still dealing with some lingering showers across parts of the Carolinas down into Florida.

Now we're still going to be seeing very hot temperatures. So our heat wave is going to continue not just for today but even over most of this work week. So 90 will be your high in New York City; 96 in Chicago and Atlanta; and upper 90's in the city of Denver. So it's going to be another scorcher. And of course Dagen when you factor in the humidity, it feels even hotter during the afternoon.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Maria Molina, our meteorologist in Fox Business.

Coming up after the break, we'll check on the markets for you. And stay tuned for an Imus family interview as the I-man gives both Deirdre Imus and his son Wyatt an opportunity to battle it out over the air waves. Stick around as this best of Imus on the Fox Business Network continues.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The live, more scandal cost Barclays chairman Marcus Agius his job, puts CEO Bob Dimon in the sights of politician who thinks Dimon has lost his sparkle and also threatens to hit other banks worldwide.

The heat coming down on bankers, but it's nothing compared to the scorcher blistering parts of the U.S. and triggering deadly storms. Millions wake up this morning without electricity while temperatures in some places top 100 degrees.

Welcome back everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell here on this Best of Imus in the Morning. We've got your markets for you and so much more. Some incredible guests coming up in the next couple of hours include Dana Perena (ph). And we'll show you a special little new addition to her family if you haven't been watching The Five. Well, shame on you if you haven't been watching The Five.

In the meantime, we'll take you around the world and look at stocks in Asia. First we had a mixed market with just slight losses in Japan and South Korea, slight gain on the Shanghai. Hong Kong closed.

But European markets are up across the board, up nearly 1 percent in Germany and then in France as well. Again, more positive reaction to the bailout decision from those European leaders last week.

We had incredible numbers on the stock market here. Stocks are essentially flat. It's going to be kind of a funny week, if you will, with the markets closed for July 4 on Wednesday. And then nothing funny about a drop in oil. We kind of love that. Oil is off its lows in the session so far, but still down about $1.50 a barrel.

But no, the states are saying forget it. Let's set aside the $25 billion foreclosure settlement. That does not stop us from issuing our own foreclosure rules, basically HARP 3.0 or HAMP 3.0, which is a federal program for the states.

So, you know, the bankers are coming out in the media saying it's going to make it difficult for us and to be able to clear that inventory if they're willy-nilly sets of rules.

We get it, we want to protect borrowers, but for the bankers, I'm sure they're going to feel like they're chasing a net in a hurricane or a moth in the hurricane, try to follow these different rules.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but do you -- again, it's the -- do you get to stay in a home when you're not making payments on a home? It's not even your home.

Yes, if you're underwater on it and if you're underwater and you have no equity in it, it's not your house and you're basically living rent- free and at what point in this country do we say, enough is enough?

MACDONALD: Yes, that's the issue, too. And also with the new rules coming, back to your point, we are going to wait for the rules to kick in, right and see how the rules play out in our own state.

You know, for example, New York State is talking about criminalizing forgery if there's in a foreclosure document, called a forgery and the issue, too, is will all the bankers out there get state by state rules and if they break the rules, would they be subject to lawsuits, even if they didn't know or had access to, weren't apprised to the rules ahead of time.

MCDOWELL: What's does it do to lending?

MACDONALD: Well, you know, the FHA doesn't like it. They've criticized it and they've criticized in the past, similar standards, right, similar ideas. And saying, freeze up credit. You know?

Banks could become gun shy and separate from that the Mortgage Bankers Association say the cost of thee different rules come down in the foreclosure rules will be passed along to future borrowers.

MCDOWELL: And makes you not want to live in one of those states or trying to find a home in one of those states.

Liz, thank you so much. Good to see you. Liz Macdonald on the Fox Business Network. She will be with you all day long. Right now, we want to go to our news room and Diane Macedo who has business headlines for you. Hi, Diane.

MACEDO: Hi, Dagen. So it's official, Dell is buying Qwest Software for $2.4 billion or $28 a share. Qwest offers software to help businesses manage their data bases. Dell's offer tops the one made by a property equity group led by insight very much partners bidding on Qwest the last few months. The deal marked Dell's latest effort to expand beyond its core business of personal computers.

And Barclay's Chairman Marcus Agius has resigned in the wake of the bank's interest rage rigging scandal. Agius who's been chairman for more than five years says the scandal has dealt a devastating blow to Barclay's reputation and buck stops with him.

He will stay on until they find a succession plan there. The bank was fined more than $450 million last week by British and U.S. regulators for submitting false documents on the London Interbank offered interest rate or Libor, which is the rate at which banks lend unsecured funds to each other.

Barclays had admitted that some of its traders attempted to manipulate that rate to make it look like the bank's borrowing costs look lower than they actually were in an attempt to make the bank and the industry in general look healthier than it actually is.

Agius' resignation is seen as an attempt to take the pressure off CEO Bob Diamond who is also facing calls to resign. Dagen, back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much. Diane, first, it was Mr. Sunday's soups and now Lorraine and Chris Wallace rejoin the I-man to talk another cookbook, this they're talking chicken. They recently sat down to talk about recipes with the I-man.

(REPEAT INTERVIEW WITH CHRIS AND LORRAINE WALLACE)

MCDOWELL: Still ahead, we have a market check and some hilarious moments from IMUS IN THE MORNING. So stick around.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANGELA SUN, TENNIS CHANNEL: Hello. This is Angela Sun for the Tennis Channel's Wimbledon Court Report here on the Fox Business Network.

Some say middle Monday in Wimbledon is the greatest day of tennis all year. Every fourth round match involved the men and women's draws are scheduled. Two remain, for the men, Djokovic, Feder and Andy Murray are the top seeds remaining in the draw and for the women, Sharapova, Victoria, and (inaudible) are also alive.

Americans are well represented, as Serena Williams, Mardy Fish and qualifier Brian Baker, still on. Baker lost only two sets in six matches.

Wimbledon prime time will have all the action nightly at 5 p.m. Eastern on Tennis Channel with extended highlights and news and interviews from the grass court slams. For the Tennis Channel Wimbledon Court Report, I'm Angela Sun.

MCDOWELL: Well, speaking of Wimbledon in England and overseas, looking at your markets around the world. First we cross the Pacific and go to Asia. And they were essentially flat except for a nice gain in Australia.

Over to Europe in England and France and Germany, you have 1 percent plus gains in France and Germany. The futures in the U.S., a mixed bag, they were up, they were down slightly and still see an 8 point loss on the Dow. But again, it was a great day and weak last week, rough quarter for stocks. Commodities, oil and gold are both lower.

There's one thing that is for certain, there's never a shortage of laughs on IMUS IN THE MORNING. Here are some of the lighter moments from the I-man and everybody else.

(BEST OF IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

urn:contentItem:5JDH-S3J1-DY0W-4238-00000-00'Fifty Shades of Grey' Hits Record Million Dollar Milestone; EADS to Invest $600 Million In Alabama Airbus Facility; Enrique Pena Nieto2012-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:39ZLexisNexis'Fifty Shades of Grey' Hits Record Million Dollar Milestone; EADS to Invest $600 Million In AlabamaAirbus Facility; Enrique Pena NietoLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: The LIBOR scandal costs Barclays Chairman Marcus Agius his job and put CEO Bob Dimon in the sites of politicians. He suspects this Dimon has lost its sparkle. And to heat other banks worldwide.

The heat coming down on bankers around the world but nothing is compared to the scorcher blistering parts of the United States and triggering deadly storms. Millions waking up this morning without electricity and temperatures in some places are over 100 degrees.

The Chinese economy anything but hot and continues to cool down. The latest PMI reading indicates that factory production and exports continues to plunge as investors wonder what happens when the world global engine begins to stall.

And what's old is new again in Mexico where voters hand power to the political party that ruled for 70 years but was swept from office more than a decade ago only to return on this Monday, July the 2nd, 2012.

Good morning, everybody. Well, I'm back from vacation. Connell is not here. He runs for the hills when he knows he has to be with me. I'm Dagen McDowell everybody. This is BEST OF IMUS.

And we've got some incredible interviews that the I-man did recently. Coming up this hour, Jose Rodriguez. And also Imus on Imus, not blonde on blonde. Deirdre, Imus and Wyatt Imus go head to head. I missed that last week and I cannot wait to see that.

Meantime, let's bring you up to date on what is happening in the global markets. And first, we start with Asia. The Hong Kong market was closed for a holiday today. And we had some mixed reaction there. Again, that reading on Chinese factory activity did come in better than expected, somewhat better than expected. The Nikkei was lower, one with the Kospi and South Korea. But the Shanghai managed to tick up just a bit. But the ASX 200 index was also higher.

We have gains across the board, potentially we follow a reaction to what happened with European leaders and the changes in that bailout facility to help Italy and Spain. We'll see if that lasts. Coming up, we'll talk to a guest from Europe, from London.

Let's take a look at the futures here in the U.S. It looks like a positive start. Again, the markets closed early tomorrow. Off on Wednesday. Very busy week for data with that critical jobs report coming out on Friday. And we have essentially flat lines there. Not flat but down. Oil and gold with gold falling almost one percent. Oil is down two percent this morning.

For more on the European markets, let's go live to London where we're joined by Jane Foley, senior foreign currency strategist for Rabobank. Jane, how long does the euphoria from that deal struck by European leaders last? Do you think that we can even get a couple more days out of this in terms of gains?

JANE FOLEY, RABOBANK SENIOR CURRENCY STRATEGIST: Well, that's really the big question and that will be the question that prevail over the next few weeks. It is quite likely that we'll get decent support from this over the next few weeks, perhaps over the next few months. But I think as we've already been seen, there was already some skepticism entering in here and there's still a lot of pit holes thrown up by what was agreed last week. And a lot of uncertainty about the details too.

You've already mentioned the banking supervisions. How long is it going to take for Europe to get a single banking supervisor? And what exactly, what should have shaken this at going to be? And there's also about the ESM too. There's been some complaints in some European countries about the seniority the announcement last week, that the ESM would not be seen here to -- holders of Spanish government debt. So, again some confusion today and therefore some backtracking. More consultative tone I think we should say in some markets in Europe this morning.

MCDOWELL: What is the next great hurdle for the European markets? What is the next meeting, piece of news that you were looking to that we can count on -- give us some direction in these markets?

FOLEY: Well, of course, we do have the ECB policy meeting on Thursday. Many people expecting a rate cut there because of course the very slow growth conditions in Europe. Beyond that, we have a finance ministers meeting on July the ninth. But that will be important because the market is expecting more detail about the purchase that were announced last week.

MCDOWELL: What also is the reaction to the resignation to the chairman of Barclays, the livewire scandal there, what it means for other banks not just in Europe but around the globe?

FOLEY: Well, of course, Barclays is one of the first banks to come through and pay the fine and be fully investigated in the scandal. But I think many people in many parts of the world are waiting for what else is going to come. And there could be further bad news ahead.

MCDOWELL: Jane, thank you so much. Jane Foley, senior foreign currency strategist for Rabobank.

Let's take a closer look at the Asian markets. And for that, we go to FOX Business contributor Katie Sargent. She joins us on the phone from Singapore. Hey, Katie, reaction to that factory report from China.

KATIE SARGENT, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: That seems to be something that's taking the markets, taking the wind out of the market sails today, Dagen. Most of the markets in the region started the day pretty strong, still kind of riding that wave of euphoria on the agreement from last week over the European banks. But that quickly waned when we started looking at PMI numbers.

We saw more evidence of a slowdown in China over the weekend. The official Purchasing Managers Index for June came out showing a drop from May. It was better than expected but still showed a drop. And there was a private PMI report released today that also showed activities shrank in June. They are a little bit in disagreement over the final number but both are showing a slowdown.

So, the session started quite positive for the region. Australia's benchmark ASX 200 was up nearly one percent. But then as I say, things slowdown, the Nikkei in Japan hit a two-month in today high before faltering and finishing the day little changed. Not much movement in the rest of the markets either -- Dagen.

MACEDO: Thank you so much, Katie. Katie Sargent on the phone from Singapore. Thank you so much.

MCDOWELL: Now, for a closer look at the U.S. markets and a preview of how things will shape up today, we go to our very own Lauren Simonetti from the Newsroom. Good morning, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning. The fireworks were lit early on Wall Street with stellar gains for the major averages. The Dow rocketing 277 points on Friday. June, great months too with gains of at least 3.8 percent for the three major averages. This first trading day of July will be a busy one and an equally busy week. National manufacturing figures on tap. Auto sales tomorrow. And that key government jobs report for June is out on Friday.

Speaking of jobs, they are moving off of Wall Street. The trend is called near shoring. It's where big financial tightened higher and relocated workers to cities like Salt Lake, City, Utah. And Jacksonville, Florida where rent, taxes and labor all cost less.

Silicon Valley is seeing a similar exodus. That's the big tech giant find saving in other U.S. cities. And how do you read it? "Fifty Shades of Grey" laying off bookstore shelves. EL James' erotic novel became the nation's fastest selling paper back to reach one million sales.

Nelson book scan (ph) finds that it took 11 weeks to reach that mark, that was 25 weeks faster than the previous record holder, "The Vinci Code." Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Lauren, thank you so much. I will say nothing about that book since I have not read it and have no plans to read it. Now, we go to our Newsroom and Diane Macedo who has a look at more business news for you this morning. Hey, Diane.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I will say nothing about the book because my mother is watching.

(LAUGHTER)

Barclays Chairman Marcus Agius has resigned in the wake of the bank's interest rate raging scandal. Agius who has been the chairman for more than five years says, the scandal has dealt a devastating blow to Barclays' reputation. And at the buck stops with him, he will stay in the position until a succession plan is in place.

You might remember the bank was fined more than $450 million last week by a British and U.S. regulators for submitting false documents on the London interbank offered interest rate, which the rate at which banks lend unsecured funds to each other. Barclays has admitted that some of its traders attempted to manipulate that rate. Agius' resignation is seen as an attempt to take some pressure off CEO Bob Dimon who along with Agius also is facing calls to resign.

Airbus is set to unveil plans for its first U.S. factory today. The company's parent, European Aeronautic Defense and Space plans to spend $600 million to build a facility in Mobile, Alabama. Once it opens in 2015, the plant is expected to create 1,000 jobs and will reportedly produce four planes a month by 2017. The move also puts the facility on the home turf of U.S. rival Boeing which has 2700 employees in Alabama as well.

Bristol-Myers Squibb is buying diabetes drug maker Amylin Pharmaceuticals for $5.3 billion. That breakdown to $31 dollars a share, nine dollars higher. And the offer Bristol-Myers reportedly made back in March. Now, if you include debt, the deal is worth a total of $7 billion.

In addition, Bristol-Myers will enter into an alliance with British drug maker Astra Zeneca to developed and commercialize Amylin's diabetes drugs. Astra Zeneca will pay Bristol-Myers $3.4 billion in that deal, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Diane. Following attacks on 9/11, the CIA was instructed to protect Americans by any means necessary. Some of the agency's methods were later questioned but a new book by former CIA operative Jose Rodriguez defends the tactics used to fight the terrorists. Rodriguez was on recently to discuss it all with the I-man.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DON IMUS, HOST, "IMUS IN THE MORNING": Please welcome to the program Jose Rodriguez, has got a book called "The Hard Measures: How Aggressive CIA Actions after 9/11 Saved Americans Lives." Mr. Rodriguez, sits here and listening to me. Juan use vial language to try and apologize for it.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes.

IMUS: And two, scream and swear at the recorded commercials which makes me pretty much a mental patient. Anyway, first of all, good morning, Mr. Rodriguez.

JOSE RODRIGUEZ, "HARD MEASURES" AUTHOR: Thank you.

IMUS: How are you?

RODRIGUEZ: Thank you for inviting me on the show.

IMUS: I saw you on "60 Minutes." How did that go?

RODRIGUEZ: That went well. You know, it was my first time out doing this. I was a 31-year CIA veteran and clandestinity was my thing. And coming out in the open like that was a new one for me. So, far so good.

IMUS: Were you covert operations for the entire 31 years?

RODRIGUEZ: I was covert operative for 31 years.

IMUS: OK. So, were you at the University of Florida? Is that where you went to school?

RODRIGUEZ: Yes, I did.

IMUS: And you were recruited there?

RODRIGUEZ: No. I left the university and I sent an application. And it takes awhile but a couple of years later, I was recruited.

IMUS: You sent an application to the CIA?

RODRIGUEZ: Yes.

RODRIGUEZ: Why did you want do that?

RODRIGUEZ: I have lived in Latin America all my life, had traveled overseas, was interested in foreign affairs, was interested in that type of life. And, you know, I was always interested in the CIA. So, when it came to time, I was very fortunate to get recruited.

IMUS: What did you tell people you do?

RODRIGUEZ: Well, usually you know, I was assigned overseas for 17 years, so I had State Department cover, so I was a State Department official forever.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes.

IMUS: So, that's what you -- they didn't know you were in the CIA?

RODRIGUEZ: Well, you know, it's kind of a game. I think most people know who you are, you know. And then when you become chief of station, you become declared to that country.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: So, the official, the local service, knows who you are. And, you know, they can tell anybody else. So, it's one of those things that you do but it doesn't matter much. You still have to do your job.

IMUS: Now, the secrets you reveal, I guess they are, in this book and the techniques, methods and all that stuff, why did you do this? Was it a good idea or?

RODRIGUEZ: No, I did not reveal any secrets.

IMUS: OK.

RODRIGUEZ: I mean, they were already exposed. As a matter of fact, President Obama released the legal opinion that has all these techniques. He did it in 2009 against the advice of a couple of CIA directors because he was concerned that he would give away to the enemy exactly the outer limits of what was permissible under U.S. law, so.

IMUS: Permissible in terms of interrogation?

RODRIGUEZ: In terms of the law, what our law permits for how far we can go, yes, in interrogating prisoners.

IMUS: OK. And so, you decided to do the book for what reason?

RODRIGUEZ: I decided to write the book to set the record straight because to me, it is unbelievable the amount of misinformation that has been out there regarding our programs after 9/11. I wrote the book because I was the subject of a criminal investigation for three years for destroying some tapes and I never got the chance to say my side of the story.

And I wrote the book because there are a lot of people who are still caught up in investigations that are very unfair and are suffering a lot because of it, because they did what our government asked them to do.

IMUS: Yes, paramount at the top tier of misinformation, what would be the biggest misconception that the general public, people like me and others, would be embracing?

RODRIGUEZ: That the enhanced interrogation techniques were torture.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: That's the top.

IMUS: Yes, it sounds to me -- of course it's just me -- but like it could have been fun but just me, but people think -- I've got a couple of people a little while ago, one of whom thought that we never got any good information, water boarding people.

RODRIGUEZ: Tat is such --

IMUS: Nonsense.

RODRIGUEZ: Can I say crap in radio?

IMUS: Yes.

RODRIGUEZ: Because we got thousands of intelligence reports. We were able to disrupt plots. We were able to capture high-level terrorists. We were able to destroy the al-Qaeda organization that attacked us on 9/11 because of the work that we did.

IMUS: So, the people say, well, when you torture people, they'll simply tell you what they think you want to hear but --

RODRIGUEZ: Well, first of all, this is not torture.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: And second of all, we're smarter than that. You know, we have people who are world experts on al-Qaeda and actually know quite a bit about these individuals already. So, we've vetted them very closely and check it. And, you know, these people eventually come through with a lot of really good stuff.

IMUS: Of course, one of you guys are lawyers. And like lawyers, you already know the answer to the question before you ask it. You just want to see if they're willing to give it to you, so.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes, I think the key is knowledge. I mean, the key to a good interrogation is knowledge. How much knowledge do you know of the target? Because if you do, then they can't fool you.

IMUS: So, leading up to the murder of -- murder, assassination, whatever of Osama -- the killing of Osama bin Laden, what led up to that?

RODRIGUEZ: As you know, it was a ten-year effort. We started to look --

IMUS: A lot of people don't know that.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes. Well, it was a ten-year effort. We started looking for Bin Laden the day after 9/11.

IMUS: Right. Well, I guess they knew that but they didn't know that it was a concentrated effort in intelligence gathering and so on. So, walk me through that if you can.

RODRIGUEZ: Yes. Interestingly, because if you had asked me in 2002, how long it would take to get Bin Laden, I would take you 18 months, two years perhaps. Because I figured eventually, we would find him. But he took himself out of the day-to-day running of al-Qaeda, and he decided he would become the symbolic figure. So, he gave up his day-to-day duties and moved to a compound in Pakistan and communicated with al-Qaeda central via courier.

And the courier would go by every two or three months to deliver messages from him to the principals of the organization. So until we found the courier, we would not be able to find Bin Laden. And finding the courier took a long time because it's one person. And we started to get some information in 2004 about the courier. We got the pseudonym of the courier...

IMUS: How did you get that? Through enhance interrogation.

RODRIGUEZ: We got that from interrogating at one of our black sites, a facilitator that we had captured.

IMUS: What is a black site?

RODRIGUEZ: A black site is the location where we would take this terrorist to, to interrogate.

IMUS: Right.

RODRIGUEZ: And it was a secure location. It was secure and secret, and we hid in plain sight in different parts of the world so that we could have total access, unrestricted access that we controlled to the detainee.

IMUS: Were you all at the agency and you and everybody, were you surprised that you turned up in Pakistan?

RODRIGUEZ: No. We always thought he was in Pakistan. So, I'm not surprised.

IMUS: Yes. Were you surprised that -- it seemed like a relatively easy -- I mean once they decided to go ahead and storm the compound, it seemed like a fairly easy operation. Maybe I'm just na[ve or --

RODRIGUEZ: No, I think, you know, we got the best Special Forces in the world, and I'm sure that they do this and do it very well. So, I think that once, you know, the hardest part is to find the guy, in my view. I think that once you have the target, our special operators can plan it and with the precision and the fire power and their skill, you know, I don't think there's anybody better in the world.

IMUS: So, what impact on the whole global terror operation did killing him have?

RODRIGUEZ: He was a symbolic figure. As I said before, he was not running operations day to day. He was sending pronouncements, I would like to attack America. I would like to, you know, do this and the other. But he had no direct impact on the day-to-day planning of operations, but he was still a symbolic figure and it was important to kill him.

IMUS: What did they -- did the CIA have to sign off on your book or?

RODRIGUEZ: Yes, they had to review it. You know, the manuscript is turned over to them. And they go through the publication review board. And they take some stuff out. And we know we discussed with them some things and take some things out. And agree on others. So, yes, it's a process.

IMUS: Congratulations. "60 Minutes" and all these other programs. You can't help but have a bestseller. I hope you do, so.

RODRIGUEZ: Thank you so much. Thanks for inviting me.

IMUS: By the way, thanks for your service to our country.

RODRIGUEZ: Thank you so much.

IMUS: Jose Rodriguez, "Hard Measures."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: When we come back, everybody, we'll have more news for you business and otherwise. Also, the latest on those deadly storms that devastated areas up and down the east coast leaving millions without power.

Plus, your business travelers forecast with Maria Molina who is watching this storm and the attempted recovery.

And later, it is Imus on Imus as Deirdre Imus takes on son Wyatt Imus. They battle it out on some very interesting topics.

PRANN: An Amtrak train traveling from New York to Chicago waylaid in West Virginia by downed trees.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: I heard the weather and heard the stuff hitting inside of the train. And next thing I know we were stopped. It was pitch- black.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: You have the power out and nothing but mountains on both sides.

PRANN: The 232 passengers eventually making it out by bus. Ohio, West Virginia, Maryland and Virginia all declared states of emergency. President Obama has reached out to the governors. Trees twisted in wires across the Washington, D.C. suburbs, crews in Virginia and Maryland trying to entangle a puzzle of power lines saying, the job requires some extra manpower.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: We requested over 1,000 crews from different parts of the country.

PRANN: Linemen working here in West Virginia in the 90-degree heat trying to restore power and relief to more than half a million customers.

(on camera) The National Weather Service calling Friday night's storm a derate (ph) show, meaning a line of thunderstorm packing damaging straight line winds some cities feeling gusts up to 90 miles per hour.

In Charleston, West Virginia, Elizabeth Prann, FOX News.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCDOWELL: Florida saying, no to two features of President Obama's health care law. Governor Rick Scott saying, the state will not comply with the Supreme Court ruling to expand Medicaid and implement insurance exchanges. Wisconsin and Louisiana two other states with republican governors also opting out of these two provisions last week. The health care law takes full effect by January 2014, but the republican lawmakers are still vowing to repeal it before then.

A fiesta of democracy, that is what Enrique Pena Nieto is calling his victory in Mexico's presidential election. The official preliminary count gives Pena Nieto about 38 percent of the vote. He is part of the institutional revolutionary party or PRI which was voted out in 2000 after 71 years in power. The president-elect is promising Mexicans a government that is democratic, modern and open to criticism. The PRI was long accused of ruling the country through authoritarian and corrupt practices.

Now let's go to our news room and Diane Macedo has more business headlines for you this morning. Hi, Diane.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS: Hi, Dagen. So General Electric is selling part of its real estate division owned by GE Capital to Ever Bank Financial for $2.5 billion. The business property unit originates and services commercial real estate loans for properties owned or leased by small and mid-sized businesses.

So that's a new deal that's out. We'll continue to give you details on it as we get them in. In the meantime, shares of Amylin Pharmaceuticals are climbing in the pre-market after Bristol-Myers Squibb announced its buying the diabetes drug maker for $5.3 billion.

That breaks down to $31 a share and $9 higher than the offer that Bristol Myers reportedly made back in March and including that the whole deal is worth a total of $7 billion.

In connection with the buyout, Bristol-Myers also will enter into an alliance with British drug maker Astrazeneca to develop and commercialize Amylin's diabetes drugs.

Astrazenaco will pay Bristol $3.4 billion in that deal. Briston- Myers says its acquisition of Amyline will hurt earnings in 2012 and 2013 by 3 cents a share.

But the diabetes market is one of the pharmaceutical industry's faster growing with global sales expected to climb to $58 billion in 2018 according to evaluate so a lot of money to be made there -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Diane. Right now, we want to get a look at business travelers forecast. For that, we go to Maria Molina who is standing by in the Fox Business Weather Center. Hi, Maria.

MARIA MOLINA, FOX BUSINESS WEATHER: Good morning, Dagen. Good to see you and today we are going to be tracking more showers and storms that are possible across parts of the southeast.

Yesterday, we saw over 800 reports of severe storms -- or severe weather from some of the storms that fired up in the overnight hours.

And we still have some lingering showers associated with those same storm systems. You can see them popping up across parts of the state of Alabama and also Georgia.

But again, much quieter for today until we head into the afternoon hours and also the evening hours, when those stronger storms are up once again.

High temperatures, it's going to be another hot day, not as bad as what we saw this weekend like on Atlanta where on Saturday you hit a high temperature at 106 degrees, breaking your all-time record for the hottest temperature.

You've seen today is still warm though, 96 for your high temperature, 96 of as well in Chicago and Minneapolis well above average for this time of year at 99 degrees, factor in the humidity and of course, it's going to feel even a little bit hotter.

New England, you're a lot cooler today, Boston expecting a high temperature at 79 with some clouds and a spotty shower with a thunderstorm possible.

I'm not expecting widespread travel delays though with that precipitation in New England. It's going to be more of the hit or miss in nature activity.

New York City and Philadelphia, expecting some sunshine and another warm day in Philadelphia with a high temperature expected at 90 degrees.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Maria Molina, our meteorologist here at Fox Business.

We have some breaking news to bring you, a deal on this Monday. Dell is buying Quest Software for $2.4 billion. Quest offered software to help manage business, businesses manages their data bases, that's $28 a share, $2.4 billion.

But it was a deal that was expected, there have been some reports that this deal was in the works and coming and now, here it is. And we'll be watching Dell stock today as well as Quest.

Coming up after the break, one of the I-man's favorite business reporters Liz Macdonald would join me in the studio live.

And later the I-man's interview with Chris and Lorraine Wallace on her latest cookbook, "Mr. Sunday's Saturday Night Chicken." Don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A scandal caused Barclay's Chairman Marcus Agius' job and put CEO Bob Diamond in the sites of politicians, expecting the Diamond lost its sparkle. Does this scandal threaten to hit other banks worldwide?

The heat coming down on bankers around the globe, but it's nothing compared to the scorcher blistering parts of the U.S. and triggering deadly storms. Millions waking up this morning without electricity and temperatures soaring over 100 in some places.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell. This is "Best of IMUS IN THE MORNING." Let's take a quick look at the markets around the globe before I get to some news on earnings.

You look at Asia, the markets were essentially flat there except for nice solid gains in Australia. You go over to Europe, you have gains across the board, north of 1 percent gains in Germany and in France, and well, almost 1 percent and on the DAX, given up some gains there, but all three markets there in the green, major markets.

On the U.S. futures, we have a bit of a loss on the Dow and Nasdaq futures and commodities have been in the tank all morning long. And kind of like that though. Oil is down a buck 50 a barrel, thereabouts, to $83.45.

And we are getting earnings from Acuity Brands, the maker of an electrical component. Reporting a profit of 82 cents, that beat expectations of 78 cents. Revenue of $487.5 million, it did come up short of revenue expectation for analysts of $491 million.

But here in the studio with me to talk about foreclosures on homes the state of California, Liz Macdonald, is ready to make it tougher for banks to foreclose, across every single state across this country. Will it do more harm than good do you think?

LIZ MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS: Yes, that's the question for bankers. They're saying it could do more harm than good because it could stop the foreclosure process, stop the housing recovery, stop the clearance of the backlog and that inventory.

And so what we're seeing is California has been fighting for its own set of foreclosure rules for about the last two years and one set of rules is coming to a vote today.

And what the issue is, what they want is, basically, stop foreclosure if a borrower is in loan modification, that could be extended for a very long time and basically the borrower could strike out that process and extend the payment process without paying anything, without paying any mortgage loan payment.

So the other issue, too, California notably is basically asking voters to approve the right to sue bankers during the foreclosure process, if they break any of their new foreclosure rules.

MCDOWELL: What about the other 50 states, Liz? Is this on a state by state basis?

MACDONALD: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And how does it fit in with that massive settlement, that foreclosure settlement, the banks?

MACDONALD: This is what's important. It's on a state by state basis. We have 25 states right now, moving ahead with their own set of foreclosure rules and basically, we didn't expect this.

And I don't think the banking industry expected it and I don't think the media saw this coming. After the $25 billion foreclosure settlement in February, basically, we thought that that was the end of it.

But no, the states are saying forget it. Let's set aside the $25 billion foreclosure settlement. That does not stop us from issuing our own foreclosure rules, basically HARP 3.0 or HAMP 3.0, which is a federal program for the states.

So, you know, the bankers are coming out in the media saying it's going to make it difficult for us and to be able to clear that inventory if they're willy-nilly sets of rules.

We get it, we want to protect borrowers, but for the bankers, I'm sure they're going to feel like they're chasing a net in a hurricane or a moth in the hurricane, try to follow these different rules.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but do you -- again, it's the -- do you get to stay in a home when you're not making payments on a home? It's not even your home.

Yes, if you're underwater on it and if you're underwater and you have no equity in it, it's not your house and you're basically living rent- free and at what point in this country do we say, enough is enough?

MACDONALD: Yes, that's the issue, too. And also with the new rules coming, back to your point, we are going to wait for the rules to kick in, right and see how the rules play out in our own state.

You know, for example, New York State is talking about criminalizing forgery if there's in a foreclosure document, called a forgery and the issue, too, is will all the bankers out there get state by state rules and if they break the rules, would they be subject to lawsuits, even if they didn't know or had access to, weren't apprised to the rules ahead of time.

MCDOWELL: What's does it do to lending?

MACDONALD: Well, you know, the FHA doesn't like it. They've criticized it and they've criticized in the past, similar standards, right, similar ideas. And saying, freeze up credit. You know?

Banks could become gun shy and separate from that the Mortgage Bankers Association say the cost of thee different rules come down in the foreclosure rules will be passed along to future borrowers.

MCDOWELL: And makes you not want to live in one of those states or trying to find a home in one of those states.

Liz, thank you so much. Good to see you. Liz Macdonald on the Fox Business Network. She will be with you all day long. Right now, we want to go to our news room and Diane Macedo who has business headlines for you. Hi, Diane.

MACEDO: Hi, Dagen. So it's official, Dell is buying Qwest Software for $2.4 billion or $28 a share. Qwest offers software to help businesses manage their data bases. Dell's offer tops the one made by a property equity group led by insight very much partners bidding on Qwest the last few months. The deal marked Dell's latest effort to expand beyond its core business of personal computers.

And Barclay's Chairman Marcus Agius has resigned in the wake of the bank's interest rage rigging scandal. Agius who's been chairman for more than five years says the scandal has dealt a devastating blow to Barclay's reputation and buck stops with him.

He will stay on until they find a succession plan there. The bank was fined more than $450 million last week by British and U.S. regulators for submitting false documents on the London Interbank offered interest rate or Libor, which is the rate at which banks lend unsecured funds to each other.

Barclays had admitted that some of its traders attempted to manipulate that rate to make it look like the bank's borrowing costs look lower than they actually were in an attempt to make the bank and the industry in general look healthier than it actually is.

Agius' resignation is seen as an attempt to take the pressure off CEO Bob Diamond who is also facing calls to resign. Dagen, back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much. Diane, first, it was Mr. Sunday's soups and now Lorraine and Chris Wallace rejoin the I-man to talk another cookbook, this they're talking chicken. They recently sat down to talk about recipes with the I-man.

(REPEAT INTERVIEW WITH CHRIS AND LORRAINE WALLACE)

MCDOWELL: Still ahead, we have a market check and some hilarious moments from IMUS IN THE MORNING. So stick around.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANGELA SUN, TENNIS CHANNEL: Hello. This is Angela Sun for the Tennis Channel's Wimbledon Court Report here on the Fox Business Network.

Some say middle Monday in Wimbledon is the greatest day of tennis all year. Every fourth round match involved the men and women's draws are scheduled. Two remain, for the men, Djokovic, Feder and Andy Murray are the top seeds remaining in the draw and for the women, Sharapova, Victoria, and (inaudible) are also alive.

Americans are well represented, as Serena Williams, Mardy Fish and qualifier Brian Baker, still on. Baker lost only two sets in six matches.

Wimbledon prime time will have all the action nightly at 5 p.m. Eastern on Tennis Channel with extended highlights and news and interviews from the grass court slams. For the Tennis Channel Wimbledon Court Report, I'm Angela Sun.

MCDOWELL: Well, speaking of Wimbledon in England and overseas, looking at your markets around the world. First we cross the Pacific and go to Asia. And they were essentially flat except for a nice gain in Australia.

Over to Europe in England and France and Germany, you have 1 percent plus gains in France and Germany. The futures in the U.S., a mixed bag, they were up, they were down slightly and still see an 8 point loss on the Dow. But again, it was a great day and weak last week, rough quarter for stocks. Commodities, oil and gold are both lower.

There's one thing that is for certain, there's never a shortage of laughs on IMUS IN THE MORNING. Here are some of the lighter moments from the I-man and everybody else.

(BEST OF IMUS EXTRA SEGMENTS)

urn:contentItem:561C-6KC1-DYG3-14H8-00000-00"Fifty Shades of Grey" Hits Record Million Dollar Milestone; EADS to Invest $600 Million In Alabama Airbus Facility; Enrique Pena Nieto Projected Winner in Mexican Presidential Race; Heatwave Wreaks Havoc On Corn Crop in the U.S.; Barclay's Chairman Marcus Agius has Resigned; Facebook Executives have Decided to Keep the Companies Stock Listed on the Nasdaq; Interview with Zach Wahls; Interview with Stuart Varney2012-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:39ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTZach Wahls, James Hughes, Dana Perino, Peter Morici, Jane Foley, David JonesNEWSBusiness070201cb.220"Fifty Shades of Grey" Hits Record Million Dollar Milestone; EADS to Invest $600 Million In Alabama Airbus Facility; Enrique Pena Nieto Projected Winner in Mexican Presidential Race; Heatwave Wreaks Havoc On Corn Crop in the U.S.; Barclay's Chairman Marcus Agius has Resigned; Facebook Executives have Decided to Keep the Companies Stock Listed on the Nasdaq; Interview with Zach Wahls; Interview with Stuart VarneyMark Ingram, Deirdre Imus, Wyatt Imus, Dagen McDowell, Katie Sargent, Lauren Simonetti, Diane Macedo, Elizabeth Prann, Maria Molina

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: The LIBOR scandal costs Barclays Chairman Marcus Agius his job and put CEO Bob Dimon in the sites of politicians. He suspects this Dimon has lost its sparkle. And to heat other banks worldwide.

The heat coming down on bankers around the world but nothing is compared to the scorcher blistering parts of the United States and triggering deadly storms. Millions waking up this morning without electricity and temperatures in some places are over 100 degrees.

The Chinese economy anything but hot and continues to cool down. The latest PMI reading indicates that factory production and exports continues to plunge as investors wonder what happens when the world global engine begins to stall.

And what's old is new again in Mexico where voters hand power to the political party that ruled for 70 years but was swept from office more than a decade ago only to return on this Monday, July the 2nd, 2012.

Good morning, everybody. Well, I'm back from vacation. Connell is not here. He runs for the hills when he knows he has to be with me. I'm Dagen McDowell everybody. This is BEST OF IMUS.

And we've got some incredible interviews that the I-man did recently. Coming up this hour, Jose Rodriguez. And also Imus on Imus, not blonde on blonde. Deirdre, Imus and Wyatt Imus go head to head. I missed that last week and I cannot wait to see that.

Meantime, let's bring you up to date on what is happening in the global markets. And first, we start with Asia. The Hong Kong market was closed for a holiday today. And we had some mixed reaction there. Again, that reading on Chinese factory activity did come in better than expected, somewhat better than expected. The Nikkei was lower, one with the Kospi and South Korea. But the Shanghai managed to tick up just a bit. But the ASX 200 index was also higher.

We have gains across the board, potentially we follow a reaction to what happened with European leaders and the changes in that bailout facility to help Italy and Spain. We'll see if that lasts. Coming up, we'll talk to a guest from Europe, from London.

Let's take a look at the futures here in the U.S. It looks like a positive start. Again, the markets closed early tomorrow. Off on Wednesday. Very busy week for data with that critical jobs report coming out on Friday. And we have essentially flat lines there. Not flat but down. Oil and gold with gold falling almost one percent. Oil is down two percent this morning.

For more on the European markets, let's go live to London where we're joined by Jane Foley, senior foreign currency strategist for Rabobank. Jane, how long does the euphoria from that deal struck by European leaders last? Do you think that we can even get a couple more days out of this in terms of gains?

JANE FOLEY, RABOBANK SENIOR CURRENCY STRATEGIST: Well, that's really the big question and that will be the question that prevail over the next few weeks. It is quite likely that we'll get decent support from this over the next few weeks, perhaps over the next few months. But I think as we've already been seen, there was already some skepticism entering in here and there's still a lot of pit holes thrown up by what was agreed last week. And a lot of uncertainty about the details too.

You've already mentioned the banking supervisions. How long is it going to take for Europe to get a single banking supervisor? And what exactly, what should have shaken this at going to be? And there's also about the ESM too. There's been some complaints in some European countries about the seniority the announcement last week, that the ESM would not be seen here to -- holders of Spanish government debt. So, again some confusion today and therefore some backtracking. More consultative tone I think we should say in some markets in Europe this morning.

MCDOWELL: What is the next great hurdle for the European markets? What is the next meeting, piece of news that you were looking to that we can count on -- give us some direction in these markets?

FOLEY: Well, of course, we do have the ECB policy meeting on Thursday. Many people expecting a rate cut there because of course the very slow growth conditions in Europe. Beyond that, we have a finance ministers meeting on July the ninth. But that will be important because the market is expecting more detail about the purchase that were announced last week.

MCDOWELL: What also is the reaction to the resignation to the chairman of Barclays, the livewire scandal there, what it means for other banks not just in Europe but around the globe?

FOLEY: Well, of course, Barclays is one of the first banks to come through and pay the fine and be fully investigated in the scandal. But I think many people in many parts of the world are waiting for what else is going to come. And there could be further bad news ahead.

MCDOWELL: Jane, thank you so much. Jane Foley, senior foreign currency strategist for Rabobank.

Let's take a closer look at the Asian markets. And for that, we go to FOX Business contributor Katie Sargent. She joins us on the phone from Singapore. Hey, Katie, reaction to that factory report from China.

KATIE SARGENT, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: That seems to be something that's taking the markets, taking the wind out of the market sails today, Dagen. Most of the markets in the region started the day pretty strong, still kind of riding that wave of euphoria on the agreement from last week over the European banks. But that quickly waned when we started looking at PMI numbers.

We saw more evidence of a slowdown in China over the weekend. The official Purchasing Managers Index for June came out showing a drop from May. It was better than expected but still showed a drop. And there was a private PMI report released today that also showed activities shrank in June. They are a little bit in disagreement over the final number but both are showing a slowdown.

So, the session started quite positive for the region. Australia's benchmark ASX 200 was up nearly one percent. But then as I say, things slowdown, the Nikkei in Japan hit a two-month in today high before faltering and finishing the day little changed. Not much movement in the rest of the markets either -- Dagen.

MACEDO: Thank you so much, Katie. Katie Sargent on the phone from Singapore. Thank you so much.

MCDOWELL: Now, for a closer look at the U.S. markets and a preview of how things will shape up today, we go to our very own Lauren Simonetti from the Newsroom. Good morning, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning. The fireworks were lit early on Wall Street with stellar gains for the major averages. The Dow rocketing 277 points on Friday. June, great months too with gains of at least 3.8 percent for the three major averages. This first trading day of July will be a busy one and an equally busy week. National manufacturing figures on tap. Auto sales tomorrow. And that key government jobs report for June is out on Friday.

Speaking of jobs, they are moving off of Wall Street. The trend is called near shoring. It's where big financial tightened higher and relocated workers to cities like Salt Lake, City, Utah. And Jacksonville, Florida where rent, taxes and labor all cost less.

Silicon Valley is seeing a similar exodus. That's the big tech giant find saving in other U.S. cities. And how do you read it? "Fifty Shades of Grey" laying off bookstore shelves. EL James' erotic novel became the nation's fastest selling paper back to reach one million sales.

Nelson book scan (ph) finds that it took 11 weeks to reach that mark, that was 25 weeks faster than the previous record holder, "The Vinci Code." Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Lauren, thank you so much. I will say nothing about that book since I have not read it and have no plans to read it. Now, we go to our Newsroom and Diane Macedo who has a look at more business news for you this morning. Hey, Diane.

DIANE MACEDO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I will say nothing about the book because my mother is watching.

(LAUGHTER)

Barclays Chairman Marcus Agius has resigned in the wake of the bank's interest rate raging scandal. Agius who has been the chairman for more than five years says, the scandal has dealt a devastating blow to Barclays' reputation. And at the buck stops with him, he will stay in the position until a succession plan is in place.

You might remember the bank was fined more than $450 million last week by a British and U.S. regulators for submitting false documents on the London interbank offered interest rate, which the rate at which banks lend unsecured funds to each other. Barclays has admitted that some of its traders attempted to manipulate that rate.
